CHAPTER 12
ANNEXATION
SECTION:
1-12-1: Authority
1-12-2: Declaration Of Policy
1-12-3: Voluntary Annexations
1-12-4: Involuntary Annexations
1-12-5: Water Or Sewer Connection
1-12-6: Amendments
1-12-7: Fees
1-12-1: AUTHORITY:
Annexation of any property to the Village shall be made in accordance with the
requirements and procedures of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/7-1-1 et.
seq.), as amended from time to time. (2022-4989, 12-5-2022)
1-12-2: DECLARATION OF POLICY:
It shall be the policy of the Village of Lisle to review and consider
annexations individually according to Illinois statutes, the terms and
conditions of the policies set forth herein and the uniqueness of each parcel
of real estate. The Board of Trustees may consider many factors when
considering annexation of a parcel, including the circumstances, benefits,
costs, and existing conditions.
All decisions to annex shall be at the discretion of the Board of Trustees of
the Village of Lisle and any decision regarding annexation does not set a
precedent for future consideration of any other annexations. (2022-4989, 12-5-
2022)
1-12-3: VOLUNTARY ANNEXATIONS:
   (A)   It is the policy of the Village of Lisle to consider most favorably
the voluntary annexation of property that is contiguous to the Village when
such annexation is initiated by the property owner.
   (B)   It is the policy of the Village of Lisle to pursue voluntary
annexation of property that meets the following factors for consideration:
      1.   Annexation will increase the Village's revenue in the form of real
estate tax receipts, local share of state income tax, motor fuel funds,
retailer's occupation tax, or other sources.
      2.   The current land use is one that is necessary within the boundaries
of the Village for purposes of a balanced economy.
      3.   Annexation of the property will provide strategic benefit to
facilitate orderly future growth.
      4.   Annexation will result in more logical and consistent boundaries for
the Village.
      5.   The property has been contiguous to the Village boundary for a
lengthy period of time.
      6.   The property directly benefits from Village's water distribution
system, sanitary sewer system, storm sewer system, road network, or other
Village services.
      7.   Annexation will not require service agreements between the Village
and other taxing bodies.
      8.   Annexation will not significantly extend travel distances or
response times for Village police services.
      9.   Annexation will not result in operational challenges that reduce
current service levels to existing Village properties, residents, and
businesses. (2022-4989, 12-5-2022)
1-12-4: INVOLUNTARY ANNEXATIONS:
   (A)   It is the policy of the Village of Lisle to pursue involuntary
annexation of property when said annexation meets the following factors for
consideration:
      1.   Annexation will increase the Village's revenue in the form of real
estate tax receipts, local share of state income tax, motor fuel funds,
retailer's occupation tax, or other sources.
      2.   The current land use is one that is necessary within the boundaries
of the Village for purposes of a balanced economy.
      3.   Annexation of the property will provide strategic benefit to
facilitate orderly future growth.
      4.   Annexation will result in more logical and consistent boundaries for
the Village.
      5.   The property has been contiguous to the Village boundary for a
lengthy period of time.
      6.   The property directly benefits from Village's water distribution
system, sanitary sewer system, storm sewer system, road network, or other
Village services.
      7.   Annexation will not require service agreements between the Village
and other taxing bodies.
      8.   Annexation will not significantly extend travel distances or
response times for Village police services.
      9.   Annexation will not result in operational challenges that reduce
current service levels to existing Village properties, residents, and
businesses. (2022-4989, 12-5-2022)
1-12-5: WATER OR SEWER CONNECTION:
   (A)   It shall be the policy of the Village of Lisle to require annexation
of property that is contiguous to the Village's corporate boundary when said
property is connecting to the Village's water distribution system or sanitary
sewer system.
   (B)   It shall be the policy of the Village of Lisle to require execution of
an agreement for annexation (pre-annexation agreement) when a property located
within the Village's planning boundary, but is not currently contiguous to the
Village's corporate boundary, is connecting the Village's water distribution
system or sanitary sewer system. (2022-4989, 12-5-2022)
1-12-6: AMENDMENTS:
A petition for an amendment to any existing annexation agreement shall be heard
and considered in the same manner as and is provided for original agreements.
(2022-4989, 12-5-2022)
1-12-7: FEES:
Annexation fees shall be as set forth in
Title 1, Chapter 20, of the Lisle Village Code.
(2022-4989, 12-5-2022)
CHAPTER 13
REAL ESTATE DISCLOSURES
SECTION:
1-13-1: Definitions
1-13-2: Applications; Requirements
1-13-3: Violations, Penalty
1-13-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter:
AGENT: A person authorized to act for another person or corporation.
APPLICANT: One who applies for any benefits on behalf of himself or some other
entity.
BENEFICIAL INTEREST: Any interest in a land trust.
BENEFICIARY: Any person, corporation, or other entity having a beneficial
interest in a land trust.
CORPORATION: A body of persons authorized by law to act together as a single
person, and, for the purpose of this chapter, includes any association, joint
stock company, syndicate or partnership.
LAND TRUST: An express agreement whereby the legal and equitable title to real
estate is held by a trustee for the benefit of beneficiaries who have the
exclusive right to manage and control said real estate.
LESSEE: One who has an interest in real estate by virtue of a lease.
NOMINEE: One designated to act for another, with limited authority.
OPTION HOLDER: One having the right to purchase real estate upon compliance
with conditions named in a contract.
STOCKHOLDER: One owning certificates of stock in a corporation or membership in
an association, joint stock company, syndicate, or partnership. (Ord. 460, 4-3-
1973; amd. Ord. 497, 2-5-1974)
1-13-2: APPLICATIONS; REQUIREMENTS:
Any application to the village board of trustees or any village boards and
commissions for authorization, benefit, license, permit, variation, zoning
amendment, planned unit development or for any annexation relating to real
estate shall be signed by the owner, lessee, option holder, agent or nominee of
either.
   (A)   If the application is made by a person other than the fee owner, it
shall be accompanied by an affidavit of the owner that the person signing the
application has authority to make the application; and the application shall
disclose the full names, addresses and telephone numbers of the applicant and
owner.
   (B)   If the applicant or the owner is a corporation, the application shall
disclose the names and addresses of the officers, directors, registered agent,
and those shareholders or members owning in excess of five percent (5%) of the
outstanding stock or interest in the corporation.
   (C)   If the applicant is a trustee, the full name, address, telephone
number, and the extent of the interest of each beneficiary must be disclosed.
   (D)   If the applicant is a beneficiary, nominee, or option holder, the
application must disclose the name, address and telephone number of those
persons or entities for whom he is acting, and if it is a corporation, the
provisions of subsection (B) of this section shall be complied with. (Ord. 460,
4-3-1973; amd. Ord. 497, 2-5-1974)
   (E)   In all applications the applicant shall present proof of ownership or
interest in the affected property (i.e., deed, title commitment, title
insurance policy, lease, contract). Applications being considered which have
been initiated by the village shall be exempt from the requirements of this
subsection. (Ord. 96-2812, 9-3-1996)
1-13-3: VIOLATIONS, PENALTY:
Any person making a false or incomplete statement in the application shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to a penalty as set out under section
1-4-1 of this title.
After a statement is determined to be falsified, missing or incorrect, a
written notice of the omission or falsification shall be sent to the applicant;
each day that elapses until the date the required information is furnished or
corrected shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 460, 4-3-1973; amd. Ord.
497, 2-5-1974)
CHAPTER 14
RECOVERY OF PROFESSIONAL FEES
SECTION:
1-14-1: Reimbursement Of Fees
1-14-1: REIMBURSEMENT OF FEES:
In the event that it is necessary for the village to retain the services of a
professional, including, but not limited to, attorneys, engineers, planners,
architects, surveyors, traffic or drainage experts, or other consultants, in
connection with any petitioner's request for the village to consider or
otherwise take action upon any zoning change, special use, planned unit
development, variation from village code, subdivision or other improvement or
development upon real property, then the petitioner and the owner of the
property shall be jointly and severally liable for payment of such professional
fees and reimbursement shall be made to the village within thirty (30) days of
receipt of an invoice for same. In addition, any expenses incurred, including,
but not limited to, mailing and copying, as a result of any such request,
application, or development application shall be reimbursed to the village in
the same manner. Further, any professional fees incurred as a direct or
indirect result of a party requesting a professional opinion or otherwise
requesting relief or assistance from the village, whether or not related to
real property, shall be reimbursed in accordance with this section if, in the
discretion of the village, a professional opinion is desired. (Ord. 89-1799, 2-
6-1989)
Failure to reimburse the village in accordance with this subsection may, in the
village's discretion, result in the refusal of any board, committee or other
governing body to consider or take action upon any further requests from a
petitioner or owner who has failed to pay in full all amounts due under this
section. Further, the village may deny any application for a grading, building
or other permit if such amounts have not been paid in full and the village may
elect to file a lien against any real property associated with such a
petitioner's request. Interest in the amount of a percentage, as established by
the village, per month shall accrue on all sums outstanding for thirty (30)
days or more.
When any professional services contemplated by this section are rendered by the
village staff, including any staff engineers, or services performed by the
assistant village manager, then, the party making the request shall reimburse
the village for its costs incurred by providing the professional services of
the village staff, at the rate as established by
Title 1, Chapter 20, “Fees, Fines, Insurance, Guarantees, and Regulatory
Measures”.
The village manager or his designee, is hereby authorized to assign requests
for professional services to village staff or to consultants as the village
manager deems appropriate.
(Ord. 85-1366, 12-2-1985; amd. Ord. 89-1799, 2-6-1989; Ord. 2021-4921, 9-20-
2021)

CHAPTER 16
PUBLIC WORKS CONTRACTS
SECTION:
1-16-1: Wage Rates For Public Works Contracts
1-16-1: WAGE RATES FOR PUBLIC WORKS CONTRACTS:
To the extent and as required by "an act regulating wages of laborers,
mechanics and other workmen employed in any public works by the state, county,
city or any public body or any political subdivision or by any one under
contract for public works", approved June 26, 1941, as amended 1 , the general
prevailing rate of wages in this locality for laborers, mechanics and the
workmen engaged in the construction of public works coming under the
jurisdiction of the village is hereby ascertained to be the same as the
prevailing rate of wages for construction work in the DuPage County area, as
determined by the department of labor of the state as of June 2, 1980, a copy
of that determination being incorporated herein by reference. The definition of
any terms appearing in this chapter which are also used in the aforesaid act
shall be the same as in said act.
Nothing herein contained shall be construed to apply said general prevailing
rate of wages, as herein ascertained, to any work or employment except public
works construction of this village to the extent required by the aforesaid act.
The village clerk shall publicly post or keep available for inspection by any
interested party in the main office of the village this determination of such
prevailing rate of wage, and said clerk shall mail a copy of this determination
to any employer, and to any association of employers and to any person or
association of employees who have filed, or file, their names and addresses,
requesting copies of any determination stating the particular rates, and the
particular class of workmen whose wages will be affected by such rates, and
shall promptly file a certified copy of this chapter with both the secretary of
state and the department of labor of the state of Illinois. (Ord. 80-938, 7-1-
1980)

CHAPTER 18
EMPLOYEE ETHICS
SECTION:
1-18-1: Regulations
1-18-1: REGULATIONS:
   (A)   The regulations of section 5-15 1  and article 10 2 of the state
officials and employees ethics act, 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/1-1 et
seq. (hereinafter referred to as the "act" in this section) are hereby adopted
by reference and made applicable to the officers and employees of this
governmental entity to the extent required by 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/
70-5.
   (B)   The solicitation or acceptance of gifts prohibited under the act, by
any officer or any employee is hereby prohibited.
   (C)   The offering or making of gifts prohibited by the act, to an officer
or employee is hereby prohibited.
   (D)   The participation in political activities prohibited under the act, by
any officer or employee is hereby prohibited.
   (E)   For purposes of this section, the terms "officer" and "employee" shall
be defined as set forth in 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/70-5(c).
   (F)   The penalties for violations of this section shall be the same as
those penalties set forth in 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/50-5 for similar
violations of the act.
   (G)   This section does not repeal or otherwise amend or modify any existing
enactment which regulates the conduct of officers and employees. To the extent
that any such existing ordinances or policies are less restrictive than this
section, however, the provisions of this section shall prevail in accordance
with the provisions of 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/70-5(a).
   (H)   Any amendment to the act that becomes effective after the effective
date of this section shall be incorporated into this section by reference and
shall be applicable to the solicitation, acceptance, offering and making of
gifts and to prohibited political activities. However, any amendment that makes
its provisions optional for adoption shall not be incorporated into this
section by reference without formal action by this governmental entity.
   (I)   If the Illinois supreme court declares the act unconstitutional in its
entirety, then this section shall be repealed as of the date that the Illinois
supreme court's decision becomes final and not subject to any further appeals
or rehearings. This section shall be deemed repealed without further action if
the act is found unconstitutional by the Illinois supreme court.
   (J)   If the Illinois supreme court declares part of the act
unconstitutional but upholds the constitutionality of the remainder of the act,
or does not address the remainder of the act, then the remainder of the act as
adopted by this section shall remain in full force and effect; however, that
part of this section relating to the part of the act found unconstitutional
shall be deemed repealed without further action by this governmental entity.
(Ord. 2005-3895, 2-21-2005)
 
Notes
1 1. 5 ILCS 430/5-15.
2 2. 5 ILCS 430/10-10 – 10-40.
CHAPTER 19
ELIGIBILITY UNDER THE PUBLIC SAFETY EMPLOYEE BENEFITS ACT
SECTION:
1-19-1: Purpose
1-19-2: Application For PSEBA Benefits
1-19-3: Application Review Process
1-19-4: Administrative Composition
1-19-5: Administrative Hearing
1-19-6: PSEBA Benefits Granted
1-19-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to provide a fair and efficient method of
determining the eligibility of an employee for the benefits enumerated under
the public safety employee benefits act 1 . All benefits provided to employees
pursuant to the public safety employee benefits act ("act") will be consistent
with the act. (Ord. 2016-4676, 9-12-2016)
 
Notes
1 1. 820 ILCS 320/1 et seq.
1-19-2: APPLICATION FOR PSEBA BENEFITS:
A PSEBA benefit application form prepared by the village shall be the standard
form required for PSEBA benefit applicants (hereafter the "applicant") to
utilize to request benefits under PSEBA. The form shall be completed and
executed by the requesting applicant and delivered to the village manager. The
applicant shall provide, along with the application, any medical records
regarding the injury, any decision by a governing public safety pension board
and supporting documentation related to such pension board decision, any
decision by the Illinois workers' compensation commission, and any additional
pertinent documentation that the applicant wants to have considered or that is
requested by the village. (Ord. 2016-4676, 9-12-2016)
1-19-3: APPLICATION REVIEW PROCESS:
   (A)   Upon receipt of a fully completed and executed PSEBA benefit
application, the village manager shall review the application and supporting
documentation, and if necessary complete additional fact finding and/or
investigation.
   (B)   The village manager shall make a written recommendation, including
reasons for the recommendation, to the village board within forty five (45)
calendar days after the later of the following:
      1.   The submission of the relevant documentation; or
      2.   The completion of the such additional fact finding or investigation
as deemed necessary or appropriate by the village manager.
   (C)   The village manager's written recommendation shall state whether:
      1.   The applicant is eligible for benefits under PSEBA; or
      2.   A hearing should be convened in order to determine whether or not
the applicant is eligible for benefits under PSEBA and shall inform the
applicant, in writing, of the decision and the reasons for the decision.
   (D)   If the village manager recommends that the applicant is eligible for
benefits under PSEBA, the recommendation shall be presented to the village
board at the next regularly scheduled village board meeting (subject to notice
provision of the open meetings act).
   (E)   The village board shall make a determination that:
      1.   The applicant is eligible for benefits under PSEBA; or
      2.   An administrative hearing should be convened in order to determine
whether or not the applicant is eligible for benefits under PSEBA. (Ord. 2016-
4676, 9-12-2016)
1-19-4: ADMINISTRATIVE COMPOSITION:
If the village board determines that a hearing should be convened, the system
of the administrative hearing shall be comprised of a hearing officer whose
power and authority and limitations are as follows:
   (A)   Power Of The Hearing Officer: The hearing officer shall have all of
the powers granted to him under common law relative to the conduct of an
administrative hearing including the power to:
      1.   Preside over all village hearings involving the public safety
employee benefits act 1 ;
      2.   Administer oaths;
      3.   Hear testimony and accept evidence that is relevant to the issue of
eligibility under the public safety employee benefits act 2 ;
      4.   Issue subpoenas to secure attendance of witnesses and the production
of relevant papers or documents upon the request of the parties or their
representatives;
      5.   Rule upon objections in the admissibility of evidence;
      6.   Preserve and authenticate the record of the hearing and all exhibits
in evidence introduced at the hearing;
      7.   Issue a determination based on the evidence presented at the
hearing, the determination of which shall be in writing and shall include a
written finding of fact, decision and order.
   (B)   Appointment Of The Hearing Officer: The mayor with the consent of the
board of trustees is hereby authorized to appoint a person to hold the position
of a hearing officer for each and every individual hearing that shall come
before this village. In making said selection, the mayor shall consider all
pertinent information, including, at a minimum:
      1.   The candidate's ability to comply with the job description as set
forth herein;
      2.   Background and performance data made available to the mayor on file
with the village or otherwise obtained by the village;
      3.   The candidate must be an attorney licensed to practice law in the
state of Illinois for at least three (3) years and have knowledge of and
experience in employment and labor law, general civil procedure, the rules of
evidence, and administrative practice. (Ord. 2016-4676, 9-12-2016)
 
Notes
1 1. 820 ILCS 320/1 et seq.
2 2. 820 ILCS 320/1 et seq.
1-19-5: ADMINISTRATIVE HEARING:
An administrative hearing shall be held to adjudicate and determine whether the
subject public safety employee is eligible for benefits under the public safety
employee benefits act 1 . If the employee is found eligible, the employee
benefits shall be consistent with the act.
   (A)   Time And Date: Hearings shall be held on the date, time and place as
established by the village with appropriate notice served upon the public
safety employee.
   (B)   Record: All hearings shall be attended by a certified court reporter
and a transcript of all proceedings shall be made by said certified court
reporter.
   (C)   Procedures: The village and the petitioning public safety employee
shall be entitled to representation by counsel at said hearing and may present
witnesses, may present testimony and documents, may cross examine opposing
witnesses, and may request the issuance of subpoenas to compel the appearance
of relevant witnesses or the production of relevant documents.
   (D)   Evidence: The rules of evidence as set forth in the Illinois code of
civil procedure shall apply.
   (E)   Final Determination: The determination by the hearing officer of
whether the petitioning public safety employee is eligible for the benefits
under the public safety employee benefits act 1 shall constitute a final
determination for the purpose of judicial review under the common law writ of
certiorari. (Ord. 2016-4676, 9-12-2016)
 
Notes
1 1. 820 ILCS 320/1 et seq.
1 1. 820 ILCS 320/1 et seq.
1-19-6: PSEBA BENEFITS GRANTED:
If the applicant is determined to be eligible for PSEBA benefits, the applicant
will be eligible to receive continued health coverage consistent with PSEBA
under the village's basic group health insurance plan. The basic group plan
shall be the least expensive plan offered by the village employees at the time
the PSEBA benefits are awarded.
If an applicant becomes eligible to receive health insurance benefits from
another source, including, but not limited to, medicare, the applicant's PSEBA
coverage may be reduced or eliminated as determined by the village consistent
with PSEBA. The village reserves the right on an annual basis to have the
applicant provide an affidavit affirming continued eligibility for PSEBA
benefits. (Ord. 2016-4676, 9-12-2016)

TITLE 2
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
CHAPTER 1
PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-1-1: Created
2-1-2: Members
2-1-3: Terms Of Members
2-1-4: Proceedings
2-1-5: Officers; Compensation
2-1-6: Planning Department
2-1-7: Hearings; Appeals; Notices
2-1-8: Stay Of Proceedings
2-1-9: Powers Of Commission
2-1-10: Preliminary Approval Of Subdivision Plats
2-1-11: Preexisting Plats Or Maps
2-1-12: References To Commission
2-1-13: Ex Officio Student Participation
2-1-1: CREATED:
A planning and zoning commission for the village is hereby created under the
authority of the Illinois municipal code, 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-1-
1 et seq. (Ord. 2003-3451, 4-7-2003, eff. 5-1-2003)
2-1-2: MEMBERS:
The planning and zoning commission shall consist of seven (7) members, one of
whom shall be the chairman and the said seven (7) members of said planning and
zoning commission shall be appointed by the president, subject to confirmation
by the corporate authorities. Members of the planning and zoning commission
shall reside within the village or within the territory contiguous with the
village. The chairman of the planning and zoning commission shall be designated
by the president, subject to confirmation by the corporate authorities. The
president, with the approval of the corporate authorities, may remove any
member or the chairman for misconduct in office or neglect of duty. (Ord. 2003-
3451, 4-7-2003, eff. 5-1-2003; amd. Ord. 2020-4884, 11-2-2020)
2-1-3: TERMS OF MEMBERS:
Members appointed by the president, confirmed by the corporate authorities,
shall serve the following terms: two (2) shall be appointed for a term of one
year, two (2) for a term of two (2) years and the remaining three (3) for a
term of three (3) years. The members and chairman so appointed shall, after the
expiration of their first term, if they are reappointed, be appointed for a
period of three (3) years and until their respective successors are appointed
and have qualified. All vacancies occurring in the planning and zoning
commission shall be filled by appointment of the president, subject to
confirmation of the corporate authorities, for the remainder of the unexpired
term in the same manner as original appointments. (Ord. 2003-3451, 4-7-2003,
eff. 5-1-2003; amd. Ord. 2020-4884, 11-2-2020)
2-1-4: PROCEEDINGS:
Meetings of the planning and zoning commission shall be held at the call of the
chairman and at such other times as the planning and zoning commission may
determine. Such chairman or, in his absence, the acting chairman, may
administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses. The presence of at
least four (4) members of the planning and zoning commission shall be necessary
to constitute a quorum.
The planning and zoning commission shall adopt its own rules of procedure and
shall keep a record of its own proceedings, showing the vote of each member
upon each question, or, if absent or failing to vote, indicating such fact, and
shall also keep records of its hearings and other official actions. Findings of
fact shall be included in the minutes of each case of a requested variation or
appeal, and the reasons for approving or denying such variation or appeal shall
be specified.
All records of proceedings, findings, determinations and actions of the
planning and zoning commission shall be filed immediately in the office of the
planning and zoning commission and shall be a public record. All meetings of
the planning and zoning commission shall be open to the public. (Ord. 2003-
3451, 4-7-2003, eff. 5-1-2003)
2-1-5: OFFICERS; COMPENSATION:
As soon as possible after the original appointment of members of said planning
and zoning commission or upon the appointment of a new member for the remainder
of an unexpired term, the president shall designate a chairman of the planning
and zoning commission subject to confirmation by the corporate authorities.
Said commission may have a secretary, a staff or both, and such other officers
as may in their judgment be necessary. All members and all officers of said
planning and zoning commission shall serve without compensation with the
exception of the secretary, who may receive such compensation as may be fixed
from time to time by the corporate authorities and as may be provided for in
the annual appropriation ordinance. The members of the planning and zoning
commission, by their chairman, shall from time to time make recommendations to
the village board of trustees with respect to compensation for the secretary of
said commission. If the planning and zoning commission deems it advisable to
obtain technical or legal advice or other professional services, it may do so,
but it first must obtain from the village board of trustees prior approval and
authority to incur any expense and said expense, before incurred, must have
been provided for in the annual appropriation ordinance or budget as amended
and as passed by the village board of trustees. The corporate authorities may
appropriate or budget such sums as they may deem proper for the maintenance and
operation of said planning and zoning commission and/or planning department
which may hereafter be created, including the salaries of all paid members and
employees; development of a planning program; preparation of regulations,
projects and programs pertinent to the development, redevelopment and renewal
of the municipality and such surrounding territory over which the municipality
exercises subdivision jurisdiction; the preparation and revision of the
official map and the exercise of such powers germane to the purposes for which
it was created, as may be conferred upon the planning and zoning commission or
planning department by ordinance. (Ord. 2003-3451, 4-7-2003, eff. 5-1-2003)
2-1-6: PLANNING DEPARTMENT:
The corporate authorities may, by ordinance, establish a planning department.
(Ord. 2003-3451, 4-7-2003, eff. 5-1-2003)
2-1-7: HEARINGS; APPEALS; NOTICES:
Appeals to the planning and zoning commission may be taken by any person
aggrieved or by any officer, department, board or bureau of the village
affected by a decision of the building commissioner and/or zoning inspector.
Such appeal shall be taken within such time as shall be prescribed by the
planning and zoning commission by general rule, by filing with the building
commissioner and with the planning and zoning commission a notice of appeal,
specifying the grounds thereof. The building commissioner shall forthwith
transmit to the planning and zoning commission all of the papers constituting
the record upon which the action appealed from was taken. (Ord. 2003-3451, 4-7-
2003, eff. 5-1-2003)
2-1-8: STAY OF PROCEEDINGS:
An appeal shall stay all proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed
from, unless the building commissioner certifies to the planning and zoning
commission after the notice of appeal has been filed with him that, by reason
of facts stated in the certificate, a stay would, in his opinion, cause
imminent peril to life or property, in which case the proceedings shall not be
stayed otherwise than by a restraining order granted by the planning and zoning
commission, or by a court of record, on application or notice to the building
commissioner on due cause shown.
The planning and zoning commission shall fix a reasonable time and place for
the hearing of the appeal, shall give due notice thereof to the parties in
interest, and shall render a decision within a reasonable time.
Any person may appear and testify at the hearing, either in person or by duly
authorized agent or attorney. (Ord. 2003-3451, 4-7-2003, eff. 5-1-2003)
2-1-9: POWERS OF COMMISSION:
Said planning and zoning commission shall, in addition to all other powers
provided by law, have the following powers:
   (A)   To prepare and recommend to the board of trustees of the village a
comprehensive plan of public improvements looking to the present and future
development of the village, which plan shall be known as the official plan of
Lisle. Such plan shall include reasonable requirements in reference to streets,
alleys and public grounds, unsubdivided lands within the corporate limits of
the village and in contiguous territory outside of and distant not more than
one and one-half (11/2) miles from such limits and not included in any city,
village or incorporated town. Said requirements to be effective whenever such
land shall be subdivided after the adoption of such plan.
   (B)   To prepare and recommend to the board of trustees from time to time
such changes in the plan as may be deemed necessary by the board of trustees or
by the planning and zoning commission; provided, however, that such change will
not affect the general principles of the plan as adopted.
   (C)   To prepare and recommend to the board of trustees from time to time
general plans for specific improvements in accordance with such official plan.
   (D)   To give aid to the officials of the village charged with the direction
of projects for improvements embraced within the official plan, to further
making of such improvements and generally promote the realization of the
official plan.
   (E)   To exercise such other powers germane to the powers granted by law and
as may be conferred by the corporate authorities of the village.
   (F)   The power to perform the duties that are set out in the zoning
regulations of the village, being in particular title 5, chapter 19 of this
code. (Ord. 2003-3451, 4-7-2003, eff. 5-1-2003)
2-1-10: PRELIMINARY APPROVAL OF SUBDIVISION PLATS 1 :
All plats of subdivision shall be submitted initially to the planning and
zoning commission for preliminary approval. The application for approval shall
show location and width of proposed streets and public ways; shall indicate
proposed location of sewers and storm drains; proposed dedication of public
grounds, if any; lot sizes; proposed easements for public utilities; and
proposed methods of sewage and waste disposal; but need not contain
specifications for proposed improvements.
The planning and zoning commission shall approve or disapprove the application
for preliminary approval within ninety (90) days of the date of application or
the filing by the applicant of the last item of required supporting data,
whichever date is later, unless such time is extended by mutual consent. If
such plat is disapproved, then within ninety (90) days the planning and zoning
commission shall furnish to the applicant a statement, in writing, setting
forth the reason for disapproval and specifying with particularity the aspects
in which the proposed plat failed to conform to the ordinances including
official map. If the plat is approved, the corporate authorities shall accept
or reject said plat within thirty (30) days after its next regular stated
meeting following the action of the planning and zoning commission. Preliminary
approval shall not qualify a plat for recording.
Application for approval of the plat shall be made not later than one year
after preliminary approval has been granted. The application must be supported
by such drawings, specifications and bond as may be necessary to demonstrate
compliance with all requirements of applicable statutes and such regulations as
the corporate authorities may provide by ordinance under law.
The applicant may elect to have final approval of the geographic part or parts
of the plat that received preliminary approval and may delay application for
approval of other parts until a later date or dates beyond one year with the
approval of the corporate authorities; provided that all facilities required to
serve the part or parts for which the final approval is sought have been
provided. In such case only, such part or parts of the plat as have received
final approval shall be recorded.
When a person submitting a plat of subdivision or resubdivision for final
approval has supplied all drawings, maps and other documents required by the
municipal ordinances to be furnished in support thereof, and if all such
material meets all municipal requirements, the corporate authorities shall
approve the proposed plat within sixty (60) days from the date of filing the
last required document or other paper or within sixty (60) days from the date
of filing application for final approval of the plat, whichever date is later.
The applicant and the corporate authorities may mutually agree to extend the
sixty (60) day period.
Any person seeking approval of a subdivision or resubdivision map or plat shall
post a good and sufficient bond with the village clerk and a penal sum
sufficient to cover the estimate made by the village engineer, or other
authorized person, of expenditures including, but not limited to, reasonable
inspection fees to be borne by the applicant, necessary to conform to the
requirements established and conditions upon completion of said requirements in
a reasonable time. The form of bond shall be a form from time to time
prescribed by the corporate authorities as will be the required surety to be
approved by the corporate authorities; provided that the village may permit the
deposit of cash or other security acceptable to the corporate authorities, to
complete the improvements required in lieu of bond, and further provided, that
no bond or securities shall be required to be filed until the corporate
authorities have approved the plat in all other respects and have notified the
applicant of such approval.
If the preliminary or final plat is approved, the village clerk shall attach a
certified copy of the order or resolution of approval to a copy of the plat. If
the proposed plat is disapproved, the order or resolution shall state the
reasons for disapproval, specifying with particularity the aspects in which the
proposed plat fails to conform to the official map. A copy of the order or
resolution shall be filed in the offices of the village clerk. (Ord. 2003-3451,
4-7-2003, eff. 5-1-2003)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 6 of this code containing the subdivision regulations of the
  village.
2-1-11: PREEXISTING PLATS OR MAPS:
The provisions of this chapter shall not affect the validity of any official
plat or map adopted and in force prior to the effective date hereof. (Ord.
2003-3451, 4-7-2003, eff. 5-1-2003)
2-1-12: REFERENCES TO COMMISSION:
Any reference within this code to either the plan commission or the zoning
board of appeals shall hereafter be seen as a reference to this combined
planning and zoning commission and any power or responsibility delegated to
either individual body shall henceforth be the power or responsibility of this
combined commission. (Ord. 2005-3906, 3-21-2005)
2-1-13: EX OFFICIO STUDENT PARTICIPATION:
   (A)   In order to encourage civic responsibility and to provide hands on
learning experiences, the high school student representative position(s) is
established for the planning and zoning commission.
   (B)   Student representatives shall be Lisle residents and open to all high
school grade levels with preference being given to qualified seniors.
   (C)   Student representatives shall be expected to attend one meeting per
month as regularly scheduled.
   (D)   Student representatives shall serve a one year term consistent with
the term of the school year.
   (E)   Student representatives who engage in improper behavior or are absent
from two (2) or more consecutive meetings without notifying the village planner
may be removed from the commission by the chairman of the planning and zoning
commission at the recommendation of the village planner.
   (F)   Student representatives shall not vote, nor are they to be considered
a member of the commission as it relates to vote counts or quorum requirements.
(Ord. 2017-4705, 2-6-2017)

137, 10-2-1962)

CHAPTER 4
SAFETY REVIEW BOARD
(Rep. by Ord. 83-1162, 11-15-1983)

CHAPTER 6
BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS
SECTION:
2-6-1: Created
2-6-2: Officers Of Board, Duties
2-6-3: Duties And Responsibilities Of Board
2-6-4: Oath And Bond Of Commissioners
2-6-1: CREATED:
There is hereby created a board of fire and police commissioners consisting of
three (3) members, whose terms of office shall be three (3) years and until
their respective successors are appointed and have qualified.
The members of said board shall possess qualifications required by state law,
and shall take the oath or affirmation of office set forth in section
2-6-4 of this chapter, and said members shall be subject to removal from office
as provided by state law. (Ord. 188, 7-6-1965; amd. 1979 Code)
2-6-2: OFFICERS OF BOARD, DUTIES:
Such board may designate one of its own members to act as secretary. The
secretary shall keep the minutes of the board's proceedings, the original of
which is to remain on file and secure in the village hall so as to avoid being
taken away from the village's possession or from being lost, and the secretary
shall be custodian of all papers pertaining to the business of the board, shall
keep a record of all examinations held, and shall perform such other duties as
the board shall prescribe. (Ord. 188, 7-6-1965; amd. 1979 Code)
2-6-3: DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES OF BOARD:
Such board of fire and police commissioners shall appoint all officers and
members of the police department of the village, except the chief of police,
which appointment shall be made by the mayor with the consent of the board of
trustees. All appointments made by the board of fire and police commissioners
shall be from the rank next below that to which the appointment shall be made,
other than that of the lowest rank.
Such board of fire and police commissioners shall make such rules and make such
appointments and removals except those herein reserved to the village president
and board of trustees, and shall have such other and further powers as are
provided by statute. (Ord. 188, 7-6-1965; amd. 1979 Code)
2-6-4: OATH AND BOND OF COMMISSIONERS:
The member commissioners of the police board of the village shall be considered
officers of the village and shall file an oath and a fidelity bond in the
amount of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) prior to their entry into and
qualification for the office of police commissioner of the village. The village
clerk shall prepare an oath to be signed on appointment, but prior to taking
office of each police commissioner of the village, and the village shall pay,
from monies budgeted or appropriated, the premium on any fidelity bond
necessary to be taken out under state law and this section in connection with
the appointment of police commissioners of the village. (Ord. 697, 6-21-1977)
CHAPTER 7
POLICE PENSION FUND BOARD OF TRUSTEES
SECTION:
2-7-1: Board Of Trustees; Designation
2-7-2: Selection Of Members
2-7-3: Term Of Office
2-7-4: Board Meetings
2-7-5: Powers And Duties Of Board
2-7-1: BOARD OF TRUSTEES; DESIGNATION:
There is hereby created a board to be known as the BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF THE
POLICE PENSION FUND, such board to be composed of five (5) members 1 . The
members appointed by the mayor shall be residents of the village, but those
elected from the regular police force, by active members and the fifth member
to be elected by and from among the beneficiaries, as hereinafter provided,
need not be residents of the village. (Ord. 194, 10-7-1965; amd. 1979 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  1-7-8 of this code for bond requirements of board.
2-7-2: SELECTION OF MEMBERS:
Two (2) members of the board shall be appointed by the mayor of the village,
the third and fourth members of said board shall be elected from the regular
police force by the active members thereof, and the fifth member shall be
elected by and from among the beneficiaries, if any, of the fund.
Following their appointment, the members so appointed shall provide for an
election of two (2) board members to be elected from the regular police force
by the active members thereof and for the election of a board member from among
the beneficiaries, if any, of the fund. The election shall be held under the
Australian ballot system, at such place or places within the village and under
such other regulations as shall be prescribed by the appointed members of the
board. The first election following the creation of the board shall take place
as soon after the appointed members take office as is possible and those
members elected shall serve until the second Tuesday of the second May after
such election. Thereafter, such members shall be elected for a term of two (2)
years, beginning on the second Tuesday of the first May after such election.
Upon the death, resignation or inability to act of any member of the board
elected under this section, his successor shall be elected for the unexpired
term at a special election, to be called by the board and conducted in the same
manner as the regular biennial election.
All members of the regular police force shall be entitled to vote only for the
police force members of the board. All beneficiaries of legal age shall be
entitled to vote only for the member chosen from among the beneficiaries. No
person shall be entitled to cast more than one ballot at such election. (Ord.
194, 10-7-1965)
2-7-3: TERM OF OFFICE:
One of the board members appointed by the mayor shall serve until the second
Tuesday in May following his appointment. The other board member appointed by
the mayor shall serve until the second Tuesday of the second May following his
appointment. The successors to any of the appointed members of the board shall
serve for two (2) years each or until their successors are appointed and
qualified. (Ord. 194, 10-7-1965)
2-7-4: BOARD MEETINGS:
The board shall hold regular quarterly meetings on the second Tuesday of July,
October, January and April annually, and special meetings as called by the
president of the board.
At the first meeting following the election of the first board members, and
thereafter at the regular July meeting, the board shall select from its members
a president, vice president, secretary and assistant secretary. The initial
officers so selected shall serve until the regular July meeting and thereafter
the term of office shall be for a period of one year and until his respective
successor is elected and qualified.
The vice president of the board shall perform the duties of president during
any vacancy in that office, or during such time as the president is absent from
the village or for any other reason is disqualified or by reason of illness or
other causes is unable to perform his duties.
The assistant secretary shall act for the secretary whenever necessary to
discharge the functions of such office. (Ord. 194, 10-7-1965)
2-7-5: POWERS AND DUTIES OF BOARD:
The board shall have the powers and duties stated in 40 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/3-132 to 5/3-140, and as hereafter altered or amended, in addition
to the other powers and duties granted it in said chapter. (Ord. 194, 10-7-
1965)
CHAPTER 8
FLOOD INFORMATION COMMITTEE
SECTION:
2-8-1: Establishment And Purpose
2-8-2: Membership And Appointment
2-8-3: Powers And Duties
2-8-4: Removal Of Members
2-8-5: Records And Public Inspection
2-8-6: Annual Report Required
2-8-1: ESTABLISHMENT AND PURPOSE:
A flood information committee for the village is created for the purpose of
developing a program for public information as part of the village's community
rating system (CRS) program. A program for public information, as defined by
CRS, is an ongoing local effort to identify, prepare, implement, and monitor a
range of public information activities that meet specific local needs as they
relate to flood protection, flood insurance, floodplain mapping, and other
flood related issues. The CRS program is a voluntary incentive program that
recognizes communities for implementing floodplain management practices that
exceed the federal minimum requirements of the national flood insurance program
to provide protection from flooding. (Ord. 2016-4635, 3-7-2016)
2-8-2: MEMBERSHIP AND APPOINTMENT:
   (A)   The committee will consist of at least five (5), but no more than nine
(9), members. The mayor, with consent of the village board of trustees, will
appoint the members as follows: three (3) members shall be appointed for a term
of three (3) years and up to four (4) members for a term of two (2) years.
Thereafter, the term of each member of the commission shall be two (2) years,
unless such appointment is to fill the unexpired term created by a vacancy,
occasioned by removal, resignation or death. All vacancies occurring in the
flood information committee shall be filled by appointment of the mayor,
subject to confirmation of the village board of trustees, for the remainder of
the unexpired term in the same manner as original appointments. Notwithstanding
the foregoing, all appointees shall hold office until their successors are
appointed.
   (B)   The village stormwater manager and village communications director are
hereby appointed to the committee, as nonvoting members. Each new or acting
stormwater manager or communications director will automatically assume the
place of his or her predecessor on the committee.
   (C)   Membership to the committee will be appointed in the following order
of priority:
      1.   Qualified floodplain residents who are registered electors of the
village who have lived in the FEMA special flood hazard area (SFHA) for at
least one year prior to the date of appointment;
      2.   Qualified floodplain landowners who are at least eighteen (18) years
of age and have owned property in the SFHA for at least one year prior to the
date of appointment;
      3.   Village of Lisle residents; and
      4.   Community stakeholders who are representatives of a school district,
a park district, or a library district serving village residents, not for
profit community organizations serving village residents, and village
businesses. (Ord. 2016-4635, 3-7-2016)
2-8-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   (A)   The duties of the committee will be:
      1.   To prepare and recommend, for consideration and adoption by the
board of trustees, a program for public information that meets the requirements
of the CRS program.
      2.   To annually monitor and evaluate the program for public information
for efficacy.
      3.   To recommend modifications to the program for public information to
the village board of trustees from time to time.
   (B)   The stormwater manager will serve as coordinator for the committee and
prepare materials for distribution and conduct such other business of the
committee as may be assigned by the committee from time to time. The
communications director will serve as secretary and keep meeting minutes and
conduct such other business of the committee as may be assigned by the
committee from time to time. (Ord. 2016-4635, 3-7-2016)
2-8-4: REMOVAL OF MEMBERS:
The mayor may remove any member of the committee whenever, in the mayor's sole
and absolute discretion, the best interests of the village are served thereby.
Committee members who are absent from two (2) or more consecutive meetings
without notifying the stormwater manager may be removed from the committee by
the mayor at the recommendation of the stormwater manager. (Ord. 2016-4635, 3-
7-2016)
2-8-5: RECORDS AND PUBLIC INSPECTION:
The committee will operate in accordance with the requirements of the open
meetings act and keep a written record of its proceedings that will be open to
public inspection during regular business hours of the village clerk's office
and subject to the freedom of information act. (Ord. 2016-4635, 3-7-2016)
2-8-6: ANNUAL REPORT REQUIRED:
The committee will submit an annual written report to the mayor and the board
of trustees no later than September 15 of each year. The report will evaluate
the implementation of the program for public information and provide
recommendations for modifications to the program for public information for the
following year. (Ord. 2016-4635, 3-7-2016)
CHAPTER 9
EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AGENCY
SECTION:
2-9-1: Establishment
2-9-2: Coordinator
2-9-3: Continuity Of Government
2-9-4: Functions
2-9-5: Service As Mobile Support Team
2-9-6: Agreements With Other Political Subdivisions
2-9-7: Local Disaster Declaration
2-9-8: Emergency Action
2-9-9: Reimbursement By State
2-9-10: Purchases And Expenditures
2-9-11: Oath
2-9-12: Office
2-9-1: ESTABLISHMENT:
There is hereby created the Lisle emergency management agency (Lisle EMA) to
prevent, minimize, repair, and alleviate injury or damage resulting from the
explosion of atomic or other means from without or by means of sabotage or by
other disloyal actions within, or from fire, flood, earthquake,
telecommunications failure, or other natural or technological causes, in
accordance with the Illinois emergency management act 1  ("the act").
The EMA shall consist of the coordinator and such additional members as may be
selected by the coordinator. (Ord. 97-2866, 4-7-1997)
 
Notes
1 1. 20 ILCS 3305/1 et seq.
2-9-2: COORDINATOR:
The coordinator of the EMA shall be appointed by the village president without
the need for consent by the village board, as may be from time to time
necessary. The coordinator shall have direct responsibility for the
organization, administration, training, and operation of the EMA, subject to
the direction and control of the mayor and board of trustees as provided by the
act. (Ord. 2001-3291, 3-5-2001)
2-9-3: CONTINUITY OF GOVERNMENT:
The principal executive officer ("PEO") of the village is the village
president. The "PEO", or the emergency interim successor, is the only
individual who can officially declare a disaster in the village. The "PEO" or
the emergency interim successor is the ultimate authority in the village during
any declared disaster, but relies directly on information and advice from the
coordinator and the village manager.
In the event that the "PEO" is unavailable, the powers of office shall be
exercised, and duties shall be discharged by the designated emergency interim
successors in the order specified. The emergency interim successors shall
exercise the powers and discharge the duties of the office to which designated
until such time as a vacancy which may exist shall be filled in accordance with
statutes to exercise the powers and discharge the duties of office.
Emergency interim successors in the following order of succession are hereby
designated for the "PEO" as follows:
   Village board:
   (A)   Senior trustee.
   (B)   Next most senior trustee.
   (C)   Most senior trustee available.
In cases in which two (2) or more trustees have served the same length of time,
seniority of those trustees will be determined as follows: The most senior
trustee will be the trustee who received the greatest number of votes in the
election in which the trustees who are tied for seniority were first elected to
the village board. If two (2) or more trustees who are tied for seniority have
served intermittent terms on the board, the vote count used to determine
seniority shall be from the election from which the trustee was elected to this
current and consecutive length of service. Trustees will be ranked for
seniority purposes by the total numbers of votes received by each individual
trustee from highest number to lowest number. Seniority will continue to be
assigned by vote totals from the above designated election to the village
board.
All emergency interim successors shall exercise the powers and discharge the
duties of an office until a successor is appointed or elected and qualified as
may be provided by the constitution, statutes, charters, and ordinances or
until the lawful incumbent is able to resume the exercise of the power and
discharge the duties of office.
All vital records shall be maintained and protected by the coordinator for use
in reestablishing governmental operations after the emergency is declared over.
(Ord. 2002-3365, 1-7-2002)
2-9-4: FUNCTIONS:
The EMA shall coordinate emergency management functions within the territorial
limits of the village as are prescribed in and by the state emergency
operations plan, and programs, orders, rules, and regulations as may be
promulgated by the Illinois emergency management agency and, in addition, shall
conduct such functions outside of those territorial limits as may be required
under mutual aid agreements and compacts as provided in the act. (Ord. 97-2866,
4-7-1997)
2-9-5: SERVICE AS MOBILE SUPPORT TEAM:
All or any members of the EMA may be designated as member of a mobile support
team created by the director of the state EMA as provided by law.
The leader of such mobile support team shall be designated as provided by the
act.
Personnel of a mobile support team, while on duty pursuant to such a call or
while engaged in regularly scheduled training exercises, whether within or
without the state, shall either:
   (A)   If they are paid employees of the village, have the powers, duties,
rights, privileges, and immunities, and receive the compensation incidental to
their employment;
   (B)   If they are not employees of the village, be entitled to at least one
dollar ($1.00) per year compensation from the state. (Ord. 97-2866, 4-7-1997)
2-9-6: AGREEMENTS WITH OTHER POLITICAL SUBDIVISIONS:
The coordinator may, in collaboration with other public agencies within his
immediate vicinity, develop or cause to be developed mutual aid arrangements
with other political subdivisions within this state for reciprocal disaster
response and recovery assistance in case a disaster is too great to be dealt
with unassisted. The mutual aid shall not, however, be effective unless and
until approved by each of the political subdivisions. The arrangements shall be
consistent with the state emergency operations plan and state emergency
management program, and in the event of a disaster, it shall be the duty of
each emergency management agency to render assistance in accordance with the
provisions of the mutual aid arrangements. (Ord. 97-2866, 4-7-1997)
2-9-7: LOCAL DISASTER DECLARATION:
A local disaster may be declared only by the "PEO" of the village, or his
emergency interim successor. It shall not be continued or renewed for a period
in excess of seven (7) days except by or with the consent of the governing
board of the village. Any order or proclamation declaring, continuing, or
terminating a local disaster shall be given prompt and general publicity and
shall be filed promptly with the village clerk.
The effect of a declaration of a local disaster is to activate the emergency
operations plan of that village and to authorize the furnishing of aid and
assistance thereunder. (Ord. 97-2866, 4-7-1997)
2-9-8: EMERGENCY ACTION:
A proclamation of a disaster by the governor shall activate the state emergency
operations plan and the village's emergency operations plan, and it shall be
authority for the deployment and use of any forces that the plan applies and
for use or distribution of any supplies, equipment, and materials and
facilities assembled, stockpiled, or arranged to be made available under the
act or any other provision of law relating to disasters. (Ord. 97-2866, 4-7-
1997)
2-9-9: REIMBURSEMENT BY STATE:
The state treasurer may receive and allocate to the appropriate fund any
reimbursement by the state to the village for expenses incident to training
members of the EMA as prescribed by the state director of EMA; compensation for
service and expenses of members of a mobile support team while serving outside
the village in response to a call by the governor or state director of the EMA,
as provided by law; and any other reimbursement made by the state incident to
EMA activities as provided by law. (Ord. 97-2866, 4-7-1997)
2-9-10: PURCHASES AND EXPENDITURES:
In carrying out the provisions of the act, the village may enter into contracts
and incur obligations necessary to place it in a position effectively to combat
the disaster; to protect the health and safety of persons; to protect property;
and to provide emergency assistance to victims of those disasters. If a
disaster occurs, the village may exercise powers vested under the act in the
light of exigencies of the disaster and, excepting mandatory constitutional
requirements, without regard to the procedures and formalities normally
prescribed by law pertaining to the performance of public work; entering into
contracts, incurring of obligations; the employment of temporary works; the
rental of equipment; the purchase of supplies and materials; and the
appropriation, expenditure, and disposition of public funds and property. (Ord.
97-2866, 4-7-1997)
2-9-11: OATH:
Each person whether compensated or noncompensated, who is appointed to serve in
any capacity in the Illinois emergency management agency or the village
emergency management agency, shall, before entering upon his duties, take an
oath, in writing, before the coordinator or before other persons authorized to
administer oaths in this state, which oath shall be filed with the coordinator
and which oath shall be substantially as follows:
   I,                                , do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I
will support, defend, and bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of
the United States and the Constitution of the State of Illinois, and the
territory, institutions and facilities thereof, both public and private,
against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I take this obligation freely,
without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and that I will well and
faithfully discharge the duties upon which I am about to enter. I do further
affirm that I do not advocate, nor am I nor have I been a member of any
political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government
of the United States or of this State by force or violence; and that during
such time as I am affiliated with the Lisle EMA organization, I will not
advocate nor become a member of any political party or organization that
advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this State
by force or violence.
(Ord. 97-2866, 4-7-1997)
2-9-12: OFFICE:
The village president and board of trustees are authorized to designate space
in a village building, or elsewhere, as may be provided for by the village
president and the board of trustees for the village EMA as its office. (Ord.
97-2866, 4-7-1997)
CHAPTER 10
PUBLIC ART AND SPECIAL EVENTS ADVISORY COMMITTEE
SECTION:
2-10-1: Establishment And Purpose
2-10-2: Membership And Appointment
2-10-3: Duties
2-10-4: Public Proceedings
2-10-1: ESTABLISHMENT AND PURPOSE:
A Public Art and Special Events Advisory Committee is hereby created to
promote, encourage, and recommend public art displays and special events that
create a positive avenue to welcome individuals to a community, attract
visitors, facilitate social interaction, develop a sense of community pride,
and enhance the quality of life of residents.
The Public Arts and Special Events Advisory Committee advises and makes
recommendations to the Village Board on matters relating to Public Art and
Special Events, including review and evaluation on matters pertaining to the
identification, planning, development, acceptance, funding, implementation of
projects and events. (Ord. 2025-5155, 7-21-2025)
2-10-2: MEMBERSHIP AND APPOINTMENT:
   (A)   The Public Arts and Special Events Advisory Committee will consist of
at least five (5) members, but no more than nine (9) members. The Mayor, with
consent of the Village Board, will appoint the members to terms of office that
do not exceed the term of the Mayor.
      The Chair of the Public Arts and Special Events Advisory Committee will
be designated by the Mayor at the time of the appointment of that member.
   (B)   The Village Manager or their designee shall serve on the Public Arts
and Special Events Advisory Committee as a non-voting member.
   (C)   A representative appointed by the Lisle Park District may serve on the
Public Arts and Special Events Advisory Committee as a non-voting member.
   (D)   Membership of the committee may be appointed from the following
      1.   Village of Lisle residents; and
      2.   Community business owners/manager. (Ord. 2025-5155, 7-21-2025)
2-10-3: DUTIES:
   (A)   The duties of the Public Arts and Special Events Advisory Committee
will be as follows:
      1.   Develop a strategic framework for arts and events that aligns with
the Village's overarching Strategic Plan, including vision, mission, goals, and
objectives;
      2.   Identify and recommend projects and events that the Village can
undertake to meet the Public Arts and Special Events Advisory Committee's
strategic framework and Village Strategic Plan;
      3.   Develop criteria, support review, and make recommendations on
funding of public art and special events through grants the Village makes
available in a given year;
      4.   Support the implementation of special events and public arts
projects with staff guidance and Village Board direction;
      5.   Establish communications and connections with community groups and
organizations that have focus and/or expertise in public art projects and
special events; and
      6.   Perform such other duties and functions as may be requested of it by
the Mayor and Village Board. (Ord. 2025-5155, 7-21-2025)
2-10-4: PUBLIC PROCEEDINGS:
   (A)   The Public Arts and Special Events Advisory Committee will operate in
accordance with the requirements of the Open Meetings Act and keep a written
record of its proceedings that will be open to public inspection during regular
business hours of the Village Clerk's Office and subject to the Freedom of
Information Act.
   (B)   All contractual obligations, expenditures, solicitations and
collections of funds shall be entered into only by appropriate Village staff,
with consent of the Village Board as needed. Advisory Committee members may not
make any commitments on the Village's behalf. (Ord. 2025-5155, 7-21-2025)
CHAPTER 11
LISLE IN TOUCH COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-11-1: Created
2-11-2: Appointment Of Members
2-11-3: Duties Of Commission
2-11-1: CREATED:
There shall be and is hereby created an advisory commission known as the Lisle
in touch commission for the purpose of developing and implementing programs
intended to educate and raise the awareness of Lisle area residents concerning
ways to raise a generation of drug free youth to break the cycle of substance
abuse in the community. (Ord. 91-2146, 5-6-1991)
2-11-2: APPOINTMENT OF MEMBERS:
   (A)   The commission shall consist of eleven (11) members, each of which
shall be appointed by the board of trustees. Of the eleven (11) members, five
(5) of the members, who shall be voting members of the commission, shall be as
follows: one member shall be an elected official of the village; one member
shall be employed by or be an elected official of the Lisle School District
202; one member shall be a member of the Lisle police department; one member
shall be employed by or be an elected official of the Lisle park district; and
one member shall be a resident who lives within the village planning
jurisdiction. Of the remaining six (6) members, who shall be nonvoting ex
officio members of the commission, there shall be one member who shall be under
the age of eighteen (18) years and attend a public or private religious school,
institution or system located within the village planning jurisdiction, the
remaining five (5) members shall be representatives of local community service
organizations (Lions Club, Rotary Club, Jaycees, Kiwanis Club, etc.); the
health service industry; youth services or community outreach organization; or
residents who live within the village planning jurisdiction.
   (B)   1.   Of the five (5) voting members, the term of appointment for the
member who is an elected official of the village, the member who is employed by
or an elected official of the Lisle School District 202, and the member who is
a resident who lives within the village planning jurisdiction shall be from
November 5, 2001, through April 30, 2002. The term of appointment for the
member who is a member of the Lisle police department and the member who is
employed by or an elected official of the Lisle park district shall be from
November 5, 2001, through April 30, 2003. Thereafter, the term of each voting
member of the commission shall be two (2) years, unless such appointment is to
fill the unexpired term created by a vacancy. Notwithstanding the foregoing,
all appointees shall hold office until their successors are appointed.
      2.   Of the six (6) nonvoting ex officio members, the term of appointment
for the member who is under the age of eighteen (18) years shall be from
November 5, 2001, through April 30, 2002. Of the remaining five (5) nonvoting
ex officio members, the term of appointment for two (2) members shall be from
November 5, 2001, through April 30, 2002, and three (3) members shall be
appointed for a term from November 5, 2001, through April 30, 2003. Thereafter,
the term of the member under the age of eighteen (18) years shall be one year
and the term of each other nonvoting ex officio member of the commission shall
be two (2) years, unless such appointment is to fill the unexpired term created
by a vacancy. Notwithstanding the foregoing, all appointees shall hold office
until their successors are appointed.
   (C)   The voting members of the commission appointed as set forth herein
shall elect from among themselves a chairman and a vice chairman to preside
over the commission meetings and to direct the business of the commission.
(Ord. 2001-3354, 10-15-2001)
   (D)   A recording secretary shall be furnished by the village to record the
minutes of each meeting and to furnish clerical and record keeping support to
the commission. (Ord. 91-2220, 11-18-1991)
   (E)   The member who is an elected official of the village shall be the
liaison between the village board and the commission. The member who is a
member of the Lisle police department shall be the liaison between the village
staff and the commission. (Ord. 99-3130, 7-6-1999)
   (F)   A quorum necessary in order to conduct business of the commission
shall be defined as any three (3) voting members of the commission. (Ord. 2001-
3354, 10-15-2001)
2-11-3: DUTIES OF COMMISSION:
   (A)   The commission shall be an advisory commission only and shall meet as
necessary to manage the business of the commission, and to discuss and make
recommendations to the board of trustees to effectuate the purposes and goals
of the commission. To the extent approved by the board of trustees, the
commission shall implement programs discussed and recommended.
   (B)   All contractual obligations, expenditures, solicitations and
collection of funds shall be entered into or made only with the express consent
of the board of trustees. (Ord. 91-2146, 5-6-1991)
CHAPTER 12
ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-12-1:    Establishment And Purpose
2-12-2:    Membership And Appointment
2-12-3:    Powers And Duties
2-12-4:    Removal Of Members
2-12-5:   Records And Public Inspection
2-12-1:   ESTABLISHMENT AND PURPOSE:
An Economic Development Commission is hereby established for the purpose of
encouraging and facilitating economic growth within the Village and function in
an advisory capacity to the Mayor and Board of Trustees. (Ord. 2025-5150, 6-2-
2025)
2-12-2:   MEMBERSHIP AND APPOINTMENT:
   (A)   The Economic Development Commission will consist of seven (7) voting
members. Members will be residents of the Village or representatives of
businesses or organizations conducting business in the Village. All members
will be appointed by mayor, with advice and consent of the board of trustees.
   (B)   Except as provided in subsection (C) of this section related to
initial terms, each appointment will be for a term of three (3) years, unless
such appointment is to fill an unexpired term resulting from a vacancy created
by removal or resignation. All vacancies occurring in the the Economic
Development Commission shall be filled by appointment of the mayor, subject to
confirmation of the board of trustees, for the remainder of the unexpired term
in the same manner as the original appointment. Notwithstanding the foregoing,
all member appointees will hold office until their successors are appointed and
confirmed.
   (C)   At the time the Economic Development Commission is first constituted,
the initial terms will be as follows: three (3) members will be appointed for a
term of three (3) years, and two (2) members for a term of two (2) years, and
two (2) members for a term of one (1) year.
   (D)   The mayor, with advice and consent of the board of trustees, will
appoint one (1) member as chairperson of the Economic Development Commission.
   (E)   The mayor, in consultation with the chairperson of the Economic
Development Commission, may appoint no more than three (3) advisory members of
the Economic Development Commission as non-voting members. (Ord. 2025-5150, 6-
2-2025)
2-12-3:   POWERS AND DUTIES:
The Economic Development Commission will act in an advisory and recommending
capacity to the mayor and board of trustees, and the duties of the Economic
Development Commission will be as follows:
   (A)   Provide input on matters to facilitate sound economic growth, business
development, and enhance quality of life within the Village.
   (B)   Examine opportunities for fostering an attractive economic climate
within the Village with respect to both existing and potential new businesses.
   (C)   Recommend additional steps and measure to promote economic growth by
retaining businesses and attracting new commerce and industry to the Village.
   (D)   Collaborate with Village elected officials and staff to realize
appropriate goals and objectives relating to sound business policies, an
increased tax base and increased employment opportunities. (Ord. 2025-5150, 6-
2-2025)
2-12-4:   REMOVAL OF MEMBERS:
The mayor may remove any member of the Economic Development Commission
whenever, in the mayor's sole and absolute discretion, the best interest of the
village is served thereby. (Ord. 2025-5150, 6-2-2025)
 2-12-5:   RECORDS AND PUBLIC INSPECTION:
The Economic Development Commission will operate in accordance with the
requirements of the Illinois Open Meetings Acts and keep written record of its
proceedings that will be open to public inspection and subject to the Illinois
Freedom of Information Act. (Ord. 2025-5150, 6-2-2025)
CHAPTER 13
LISLE TECHNOLOGY COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-13-1: Created
2-13-2: Appointment Of Members
2-13-3: Duties Of Commission
2-13-1: CREATED:
There shall be and is hereby created an advisory commission known as the Lisle
technology commission for the purpose of advising the village board of trustees
regarding the use of available technology by village government to provide high
quality and cost efficient benefits to the residents and businesses of the
village of Lisle. (Ord. 2001-3324, 7-2-2001)
2-13-2: APPOINTMENT OF MEMBERS:
   (A)   The commission shall consist of seven (7) members, each of which shall
be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the board of trustees.
Members shall be appointed as follows: three (3) members shall be appointed for
a term of one year; and four (4) members shall be appointed for a term of two
(2) years. Thereafter, the term of a member of the commission shall be two (2)
years, unless such appointment is to fill the unexpired term created by a
vacancy. Notwithstanding the foregoing, all appointees shall hold office until
their successors are appointed.
   (B)   The members appointed as set forth herein shall elect from among
themselves a chairman and a vice chairman to preside over the commission
meetings and to direct the business of the commission. (Ord. 2001-3324, 7-2-
2001)
2-13-3: DUTIES OF COMMISSION:
   (A)   The commission shall be an advisory commission only and shall meet as
necessary to manage the business of the commission, and to discuss and make
recommendations to the board of trustees to effectuate the purposes and goals
of the commission. To the extent approved by the board of trustees, the
commission shall implement programs discussed and recommended.
   (B)   All contractual obligations, expenditures, solicitations and
collection of funds shall be entered into or made only with the express consent
of the board of trustees. (Ord. 2001-3324, 7-2-2001)

Members shall be appointed as follows: three (3) members shall be appointed for

(2) years. Thereafter, the term of a member of the commission shall be two (2)
years, unless such appointment is to fill the unexpired term created by a
vacancy. Notwithstanding the foregoing, all appointees shall hold office until
their successors are appointed.
   (B)   The members appointed as set forth herein shall elect from among

meetings and to direct the business of the commission. (Ord. 2001-3325, 7-2-
2001)
2-14-3: DUTIES OF COMMISSION:
   (A)   The commission shall be an advisory commission only and shall meet as
necessary to manage the business of the commission, and to discuss and make
recommendations to the board of trustees to effectuate the purposes and goals
of the commission. To the extent approved by the board of trustees, the
commission shall implement programs discussed and recommended.
   (B)   All contractual obligations, expenditures, solicitations and
collection of funds shall be entered into or made only with the express consent
of the board of trustees. (Ord. 2001-3325, 7-2-2001)
