10-1-11: TEMPORARY PARKING RESTRICTIONS:
The chief of police is hereby vested with the authority to direct, control and
regulate traffic through the temporary designation and posting of signs or
other traffic control devices. Any sign or device posted per order of the chief
of police shall be deemed an official sign and shall be valid for as long as
public safety requires. (Ord. 96-2754, 3-18-1996)
10-1-12: AUTOMATED TRAFFIC LAW ENFORCEMENT SYSTEM:
   (A)   Definitions:
      AUTOMATED TRAFFIC LAW ENFORCEMENT SYSTEM: A device within the village
with one or more motor vehicle sensors working in conjunction with a red light
signal to produce recorded images of motor vehicles entering an intersection
against a steady or flashing red signal indication in violation of 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/11-306, or similar violation of this code.
      DISREGARDING A TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICE: Failure to stop and remain stopped
before an intersection that is controlled by a red signal as provided for in
625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-306.
      NO TURN ON RED: Failure to stop and remain stopped, and not proceeding to
turn right at, an intersection controlled by both a sign indicating "No turn on
red", or other similar language, and a red signal as provided for in 625
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-306.
      RECORDED IMAGES: Images produced by the automated traffic law enforcement
system, which consist of either two (2) or more photographs; two (2) or more
microphotographs; two (2) or more electronic images; or, a video recording
showing the motor vehicle and, on at least one image or portion of the
recording, clearly identifying the registration plate number of the motor
vehicle.
      TRAFFIC COMPLIANCE ADMINISTRATOR: The person appointed as such through
625 Illinois Compiled Statutes article 25 who shall have power to adopt,
distribute and process automated traffic law violation notices and other
notices required by this article, collect money paid as fines and penalties,
operate the automated traffic law enforcement system, and make certified
reports to the secretary of state as required by this article.
   (B)   Violations: It shall be a violation of this section for a vehicle to
disregard a traffic control device or turn on red in violation of 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/11-306.
   (C)   Administrative Adjudication: For purposes of administrative
adjudication of violations of this section, there is hereby established an
administrative hearing system pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-
2.1-1, which is incorporated herein as though fully set forth. The village
manager shall appoint one or more hearing officers in accordance with 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-2.1-1. The jurisdiction of the administrative
adjudication system shall include only violations of this section.
   (D)   Defenses: The following may be considered defenses by the hearing
officer for a violation of subsection (B) of this section:
      1.   That the motor vehicle or registration plates of the motor vehicle
were stolen before the violation occurred, and not under the control of or in
the possession of the owner at the time of the violation;
      2.   That the driver of the vehicle passed through the intersection when
the light was red either: a) in order to yield the right of way to an emergency
vehicle or b) as part of a funeral procession.
To demonstrate that the motor vehicle or the registration plates were stolen
before the violation occurred and were not under the control or possession of
the owner at the time of the violation, the owner must submit proof that a
report concerning the stolen motor vehicle or registration plates was filed
with a law enforcement agency in a timely manner.
   (E)   Notice Of Violation: When the automated traffic law enforcement system
records a motor vehicle entering an intersection in violation of subsection (B)
of this section, the village shall issue a written notice of violation to the
registered owner or lessee of the vehicle, which shall be delivered by U.S.
mail within thirty (30) days after the Illinois secretary of state notifies the
village of the identity of the registered owner or lessee of the vehicle, and
in no event later than ninety (90) days following the violation. The village
shall only be required to notify a lessee if the leasing company/lessor
provides the lessee's name by an affidavit and a copy of the lease within sixty
(60) days of the notice's issuance. If the driver information is not provided
within sixty (60) days, the leasing company/lessor may be found liable. If any
notice to an address is returned as undeliverable, a second notice shall be
sent to the last known address recorded in a United States post office approved
database of the owner or lessee of the cited vehicle. The second notice shall
be made by first class mail, postage prepaid. (Ord. 2007-4139, 9-10-2007)
   A notice of violation associated with an automated traffic law violation
shall require a review of the associated recorded image by the traffic
compliance administrator, who shall inspect the image and determine whether the
motor vehicle was being operated in violation of subsection (B) of this
section, or whether one of the defenses enumerated in subsection (D) of this
section is visibly applicable upon inspection. All violations must be reviewed
and approved by a law enforcement officer or retired law enforcement officer of
the village. Upon determination that the recorded image captures a violation
and that no defense applies, the notice of violation shall be served upon the
registered vehicle owner in the manner provided for above. The traffic
compliance administrator shall retain a copy of all violation notices, recorded
images and other correspondence mailed to the owner of the vehicle. Each notice
of violation shall constitute evidence of the facts contained in the notice and
is admissible in any proceeding alleging a violation of the above noted
statutory and local provisions and shall be prima facie evidence of a
violation, subject to rebuttal on the basis of the defenses established in this
section. (Ord. 2007-4139, 9-10-2007; amd. Ord. 2010-4358, 12-20-2010)
   The notice of violation shall include the following information:
      1.   The name and address of the registered owner or lessee of the
vehicle, as indicated by the records of the secretary of state, or, if such
information is outdated or unattainable, then the last known address recorded
in a United States post office approved database;
      2.   The make (only if discernable) and registration number of the motor
vehicle involved in the violation;
      3.   The violation charged;
      4.   The location where the violation occurred;
      5.   The date and time of the violation; (Ord. 2007-4139, 9-10-2007)
      6.   A copy of the recorded images, and a website address at which an
alleged violator may have access to the recorded images through the internet;
      7.   The amount of the civil penalty and the date by which the penalty
should be paid (14 days from the date of issuance) and a statement that the
payment of the fine shall operate as a final disposition of the violation;
(Ord. 2010-4358, 12-20-2010)
      8.   A statement that a failure to pay the civil penalty by the date
noted may result in an additional late fee being assessed against the owner or
lessee;
      9.   The amount of the late fee;
      10.   A statement that the failure to pay by the date specified will
result in a final determination of liability and may result in the suspension
of driving privileges for the registered owner of the vehicle;
      11.   A statement that the recorded images constitute prima facie
evidence of a violation;
      12.   A statement that the person may elect to proceed by paying the fine
or challenging the charge in court, by mail or by administrative hearing; and
      13.   A statement of how an administrative hearing may be requested.
(Ord. 2007-4139, 9-10-2007)
   (F)   Hearing: The owner of a vehicle being operated in violation of this
section may request a hearing by the respond-by date on the notice of violation
(14 days from the date of issuance), to challenge the evidence or set forth an
applicable defense. The notice of violation shall constitute evidence of the
facts contained in the notice and is admissible in any proceeding alleging a
violation of this section. The notice of violation shall be prima facie
evidence of a violation, subject to rebuttal on the basis of the defenses
established in this section. (Ord. 2007-4139, 9-10-2007; amd. Ord. 2010-4358,
12-20-2010)
   The owner's failure to appear at the hearing will result in a finding of
liability. In the event of a failure to appear, a "findings, decision and
order" letter will be sent to the owner. The owner's failure to pay the amount
by the date specified in that letter will result in a final determination.
   (G)   Nonresidents: Where the registered owner or lessee of the cited
vehicle is not a resident of the village but seeks to contest the merits of the
alleged violation, such person may contest the charges using the same available
defenses as stated above, but rather than attend the administrative hearing,
they may submit any and all documentary evidence to the traffic compliance
administrator no later than the hearing date, together with a written statement
reflecting that they are nonresidents of the village. The traffic compliance
administrator shall forward all timely submitted materials to the hearing
officer for review and determination. (Ord. 2007-4139, 9-10-2007)
   (H)   Final Determination: A final determination of an automated traffic law
violation(s) liability shall occur:
      1.   Following the failure to pay the total assessed fine or penalty
after the hearing officer's determination of an automated traffic law violation
(s) liability within twenty five (25) days and the exhaustion of or the failure
to exhaust any administrative review procedures hereinafter set forth, or
      2.   Where a person fails to appear at the hearing for an automated
traffic law violation on the date and at the time and place specified in a
prior mailed notice. The hearing officer's determination of an automated
traffic law violation(s) liability shall become final upon the exhaustion of or
the failure to exhaust any administrative or judicial review procedures
hereinafter set forth:
         (a)   Upon denial of a timely petition to set aside that
determination, or
         (b)   Upon the expiration of the period for filing a petition without
a filing having been made.
   (I)   Notice Of Determination Of Liability: A determination of automated
traffic law violation liability shall occur following failure to pay the fine
or penalty, or to contest the alleged violation within fourteen (14) days of
the notice of violation. Where a person fails to appear at a hearing to contest
the alleged violation in the time and manner specified in a prior mailed
notice, the hearing officer will enter findings, decision and order's
determination of automated traffic law violation liability which shall become
final: 1) upon denial of a timely petition to set aside that determination, or
2) upon expiration of the period for filing such a petition without a filing
having been made. If a person appears at a hearing and is found liable or
contests the violation by mail and is found liable, the hearing officer will
enter findings, decision and order, which is a final determination of automated
traffic law violation liability that is a final, appealable order.
The owner (or lessee) of a motor vehicle is subject to a penalty as set forth
in
Title 1, Chapter 20, “Fees, Fines, Insurance, Guarantees, and Regulatory
Measures”. In the event that such penalty is not paid within fourteen (14) days
after service of a final determination of liability, an additional late payment
penalty shall be imposed as set forth in Title 1, Chapter 20, “Fees, Fines,
Insurance, Guarantees, and Regulatory Measures”. A penalty shall not apply if
the driver of the motor vehicle received a uniform traffic citation from a
police officer at the time of the violation. The village shall not charge court
costs or hearing fees to persons found liable after exercising their right to
appear and contest the violation at an administrative hearing. (Ord. 2010-4358,
12-20-2010; amd. Ord. 2021-4921, 9-20-2021)
   (J)   Notice Of Final Determination: A notice of final determination shall
be sent following the final determination of automated traffic law violation
liability and the conclusion of judicial review. The notice of final
determination shall include the following information:
      1.   A statement that the unpaid fine is a debt due and owing to the
village;
      2.   A warning that a failure to pay any fine due and owing to the
village of Lisle within fourteen (14) days may result in a petition to the
circuit court of DuPage County to have the unpaid fine rendered as a judgment
or may result in the suspension of the person's driver's license for failure to
pay fines or penalties for five (5) or more violations under this section.
   (K)   Petitions To Set Aside Determination: A petition to set aside
determination of an automated traffic law violation must be filed with or
mailed to the traffic control administrator within fourteen (14) days of the
date of mailing of the notice of determination of liability. The grounds for
the petition are limited to:
      1.   The person was not the owner or lessee of the cited vehicle on the
date the violation notice was issued;
      2.   The person having already paid the fine for the violation in
question; and
      3.   Excusable failure to appear at or request a new date for a hearing.
   Upon receipt of a timely petition to set aside the determination of
liability, the hearing officer shall review the petition to determine if cause
has been shown to set aside the determination. If cause has been shown, the
village shall forward the petitioner a new hearing date on which the petitioner
must appear to present his case. The village shall notify the petitioner of the
hearing officer's decision to grant a hearing or deny the petition within
fourteen (14) days of the village's receipt.
   (L)   Notice Of Impending Driver's License Suspension: A notice of impending
driver's license suspension shall be sent to the person liable for any fine or
penalty that remains due and owing on five (5) or more violations of this
section. The notice of impending driver's license suspension shall state the
following information:
      1.   The failure to pay the fine owing within forty five (45) days of the
notice's date will result in the village notifying the secretary of state that
the person is eligible for initiation of suspension proceedings under 625
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-306.5;
      2.   A statement that the person may obtain a copy of the original ticket
imposing a fine by sending a self-addressed, stamped envelope to the village
along with a request for the copy.
   The notice of impending driver's license suspension shall be sent by first
class mail, postage prepaid, to the address recorded with the secretary of
state or, if any notice to that address is returned as undeliverable, to the
last known address recorded in a United States post office approved database.
   (M)   Driver's License Suspension: The traffic compliance administrator, by
certified report, may request that the secretary of state suspend the driving
privileges of an owner of a registered vehicle who has failed to pay any fine
or penalty due and owing as a result of five (5) automated traffic violations.
The report shall be certified and contain the following:
      1.   The name, last known address as recorded with the secretary of
state, as provided by the lessor of the cited vehicle at the time of lease, or
as recorded in a United States post office approved database if any notice sent
under this section is returned as undeliverable, and driver's license number of
the person who failed to pay the fine or penalty and the registration number of
any vehicle known to be registered to such person in a state;
      2.   A statement that the report is being made by the village of Lisle
pursuant to this section; and
      3.   A statement that a notice of impending driver's license suspension
has been sent to the person named in the report at the address recorded with
the secretary of state or at the last address known to the lessor of the cited
vehicle at the time of the lease or, if any notice sent under this section is
returned as undeliverable at the last known address recorded at a United States
post office approved database; the date on which such notice was sent; and
address to which such notice was sent.
   The traffic compliance administrator shall notify the secretary of state
whenever a person named in the certified report has paid the previously
recorded fine or penalty or whenever the municipality determines that the
original report was in error. A certified copy of such notification shall also
be given upon request and at no additional charge to the person named therein.
   Any person receiving notice from the secretary of state that their driving
privileges may be suspended at the end of a specified period may challenge the
accuracy of the certified report prepared by the traffic compliance
administrator. The person shall, within seven (7) days after having received
notice from the secretary of state, request an opportunity to speak with the
traffic compliance administrator to challenge the accuracy of the certified
report. If the traffic compliance administrator determines that the original
report was in error due to the fact that the person challenging the report was
not the owner or lessee of the vehicle or that the person has already paid the
fine for the five (5) or more automated traffic violations, the traffic
compliance administrator shall immediately notify the secretary of state of
such error in a subsequent certified report. (Ord. 2007-4139, 9-10-2007)
10-1-13: TOW AND IMPOUNDMENT OF MOTOR VEHICLES:
   (A)   Definitions: For the purpose of this section, the following
definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning:
      AGGRAVATED ASSAULT AND AGGRAVATED BATTERY: A violation of 720 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/12-2 and 5/12-4, respectively.
      ARMED ROBBERY: A violation of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/18-2.
      BURGLARY AND RESIDENTIAL BURGLARY: A violation of 720 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/19-1 and 5/19-3, respectively.
      CONTROLLED SUBSTANCE: Any substance as defined and included in the
schedules contained in article II of the Illinois controlled substance act 1 ,
as amended from time to time, and cannabis as defined in section 3 of the
cannabis control act 2 , as amended from time to time.
      CRIMINAL DAMAGE TO PROPERTY: A violation of 720 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/21-1.
      DRIVING UNDER THE INFLUENCE: Any violation as defined in 11-501 of the
Illinois vehicle code 3 , as amended.
      DRIVING WHILE LICENSE, PERMIT OR PRIVILEGE TO OPERATE A MOTOR VEHICLE IS
SUSPENDED OR REVOKED: Any violation as defined in 6-303 of the Illinois vehicle
code 4 , as amended.
      DRUG PARAPHERNALIA: Any equipment, product and/or materials as defined in
section 2 of the drug paraphernalia act 5 .
      HEARING OFFICER: A licensed attorney who is not an officer.
      OPERATION OF MOTOR VEHICLE WITHOUT A VALID DRIVER'S LICENSE: A violation
of 6-101 and/or 6-303 of the Illinois vehicle code 6 , as amended from time to
time, where the driver's license or driving privileges have been suspended,
revoked, canceled, never obtained or previously had been obtained and have been
expired for not less than six (6) months.
      OWNER OF RECORD: The record titleholder to a motor vehicle.
      RETAIL THEFT: A violation of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/16A-3.
      UNLAWFUL USE OF WEAPONS: A violation of 24-1 of the criminal code of 1961
1 , as amended.
   (B)   Vehicles Subject To Tow And Impoundment: A motor vehicle, operated
with the permission, express or implied, of the owner of record, shall be
declared to be a public nuisance and shall be subject to tow and impoundment
under this section where such motor vehicle is used in the commission of any of
the violations of village or state laws or regulations specified in this
subsection and where impoundment of the vehicle is determined by a police
officer on the scene to be reasonably necessary as a community caretaking
function so that the vehicle does not jeopardize public safety and the
efficient movement of vehicular traffic. It shall not be necessary for criminal
charges to be filed, prosecuted, and/or proven in order to demonstrate that one
of the following violations has been committed in order to trigger the towing
and impoundment of the offending vehicle:
      1.   The possession or delivery of a controlled substance or drug
paraphernalia; or
      2.   Driving while under the influence of alcohol, other drug or drugs,
intoxicating compound or compounds or any combination thereof; or
      3.   Driving while license, permit or privilege to operate a motor
vehicle is suspended or revoked in violation of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/6-303, except a person whose driver's license, permit or privilege to operate
a motor vehicle is suspended only for a violation of the vehicle emissions
inspection law of 2005, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/13C-1 et seq.; or
      4.   Operation of a motor vehicle without a valid and current driver's
license in violation of statutes including, but not limited to, either 625
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-101(a) or 5/6-101(b); or
      5.   The unlawful possession of a firearm in violation of 720 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/24-3.1, use of weapons in violation of 720 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/24-1, or discharge of a firearm in violation of 720
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-1.5; or
      6.   Retail theft, when the value of the merchandise exceeds one hundred
fifty dollars ($150.00); or
      7.   Aggravated assault, aggravated battery, armed robbery, burglary,
residential burglary and criminal damage to property; or
      8.   Any violation of the provisions of the Illinois cannabis control
act, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 550/1; or
      9.   Fleeing or attempting to elude a law enforcement officer in
violation of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-204; or
      10.   Driving recklessly in violation of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/11-503; or
      11.   Street racing in violation of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-
506; or
      12.   The commission or attempted commission of any felony offense; or
      13.   The motor vehicle is otherwise subject to seizure and impoundment
pursuant to 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/36-1.
   (C)   Tow And Impoundment Of Vehicles: Whenever a police officer has
probable cause to believe that a motor vehicle is subject to tow and
impoundment pursuant to this section, and none of the circumstances delineated
in subsection (D) of this section are present, the police officer shall cause
the motor vehicle to be towed to a facility authorized by the village or its
agents in accordance with the procedures set forth in title 9, chapter 9 of
this code. When the vehicle is towed, the police officer shall notify any
person identifying himself or herself as the owner of the vehicle or any person
who is found to be in control of the vehicle at the time of the alleged
violation, if there is such a person, of the fact of the tow and of the vehicle
owner's right to request a preliminary hearing to be held in accordance with
the administrative hearing procedures set forth in subsection
10-1-12(F) of this chapter, though the owner is not restricted to the defenses
enumerated in subsection
10-1-12(D) of this chapter. Said motor vehicle shall be impounded pending the
completion of the hearings provided for in this chapter, unless the owner of
the motor vehicle posts with the village a cash bond as set forth in subsection
(E) of this section and in an amount established by
Title 1, Chapter 20, “Fees, Fines, Insurance, Guarantees, and Regulatory
Measures”.
   (D)   Exceptions To Vehicle Tow And Impoundment: A police officer who has
probable cause to believe that a motor vehicle is subject to tow and
impoundment pursuant to this section shall first ascertain whether the tow and
impoundment is necessary and reasonable under the circumstances. If in the
judgment of the police officer then present, a person authorized by the owner
of record or the operator of the vehicle is present, capable and willing to
provide for the lawful immediate removal of the vehicle and the owner or
operator of the vehicle executes an indemnification agreement, holding the
village harmless for releasing the motor vehicle into the custody of said
person, the police officer shall allow that individual to promptly remove the
motor vehicle without it being subject to tow and impoundment.
   (E)   Posting A Bond: If a bond is posted with the village, the impounded
vehicle shall be released to the owner of record, upon the payment by the owner
of record of the towing and storage costs to the applicable towing company. If
an administrative fee is imposed pursuant to this section and established by
Title 1, Chapter 20, “Fees, Fines, Insurance, Guarantees, and Regulatory
Measures”, the bond shall be applied to said fee; provided, in the event that a
violation of this section is not proven at the hearing referenced in subsection
(C) of this section, the bond shall be returned to the person posting the bond.
All bond money posted pursuant to this section shall be held by the village
until the hearing officer issues a decision, or, in the event of judicial
review, until a reviewing court issues a final decision.
   (F)   Preliminary Hearing: Where the owner of a motor vehicle seized under
the provisions of this section requests in writing a preliminary hearing within
twelve (12) hours after the tow of the motor vehicle, the watch commander or
designated supervising officer must conduct a preliminary hearing within twenty
four (24) hours after the request for a preliminary hearing is received by the
village; provided that if the date for the hearing falls on a Saturday, Sunday,
or legal holiday, the preliminary hearing will be held on the next business day
following the Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday. For purposes of this section,
the following shall apply:
      1.   All interested persons shall be given a reasonable opportunity to be
heard at the preliminary hearing.
      2.   The formal rules of evidence shall not apply at the hearing, and
hearsay testimony will be allowed and shall be admissible.
      3.   If, after the conclusion of the hearing, the watch commander or
designated supervising officer determines that there is probable cause to
believe that the vehicle was properly towed and impounded in accordance with
this section and that no enumerated exception justifies release of the vehicle
from impoundment, he or she shall order the continued impoundment of the
vehicle unless and until the owner of the vehicle posts a cash or certified
check bond with the village, and pays all towing and storage costs to the
applicable towing company. The village shall hold the cash or certified check
bond, together with payment for all accrued towing and storage charges, until
such time as the final hearing is completed.
      4.   If the watch commander or designated supervising officer determines
that there is not probable cause to believe that the vehicle was properly towed
and impounded under this section, then the motor vehicle shall be returned to
the owner of record of the vehicle without any penalty or other costs.
   (G)   Final Hearing:
      1.   Notice Of Hearing: Within twenty one (21) days after a motor vehicle
is towed and impounded pursuant to this section, the village shall notify the
owner of record of the vehicle of the date, time and location of a final
hearing, to be conducted in accordance with subsection
10-1-12(F) of this chapter. Such notice shall be mailed by certified mail,
return receipt requested, to the owner of record, as shown on the records of
the Illinois secretary of state. Notice by certified mail need not be given
when the owner of the vehicle has been personally served with notice in written
form of the time, date and location of the hearing.
      2.   Hearing: For purposes of this section, the following shall apply at
an owner's final hearing:
         (a)   Unless continued by order of the hearing officer, the hearing
shall be held within forty five (45) days after the motor vehicle was
impounded.
         (b)   All interested persons shall be given a reasonable opportunity
to be heard at the hearing. The formal rules of evidence shall not apply at the
hearing and hearsay evidence shall be admissible. At the hearing, the violation
citation shall be prima facie evidence that the violation was committed as
provided in the citation, and the burden of proof shall be upon the defendant
to prove that the violation was not committed.
         (c)   If, after the conclusion of the hearing, the hearing officer
determines by a preponderance of the evidence that the vehicle was properly
impounded, the hearing officer shall enter an order for the continued
impoundment of the vehicle until the owner of the vehicle pays to the village
the administrative fee, as established by
Title 1, Chapter 20, “Fees, Fines, Insurance, Guarantees, and Regulatory
Measures”, plus all accrued towing and storage costs to the applicable towing
company. The administrative fee shall be a debt due to the village and the
owner shall be civilly liable therefor. If a cash bond has been posted, said
bond shall be applied to the administrative fee.
         (d)   If the owner of record fails to appear at the hearing, the
hearing officer shall enter an order of default in favor of the village, which
order shall require the payment to the village of an administrative penalty, as
established in Title 1, Chapter 20, “Fees, Fines, Insurance, Guarantees, and
Regulatory Measures”, plus towing and storage costs to the applicable towing
company, as well as the continued impoundment of the vehicle until the owner
remits to the village the administrative fee and towing and storage costs to
the towing company.
         (e)   If the hearing officer determines that the vehicle was not used
in violation of this section then the motor vehicle shall be returned to the
owner of the vehicle promptly and without any penalty or other costs, or, if a
cash bond had previously been posted, said cash bond shall be returned.
   (H)   Unclaimed Vehicles:
      1.   Any motor vehicle that is not claimed within thirty (30) days after
the expiration of time in which the owner of record may seek judicial review of
the action of the village under this section or any vehicle for which payment
of all required monies to secure the vehicle has not been tendered within
thirty (30) days of the expiration of time in which the owner of record may
seek judicial review of the order entered at the conclusion of the final
hearing, or the time at which a final judgment is rendered in favor of the
village by a court of proper jurisdiction, or the time at which a final
administrative decision is rendered against an owner of record who is in
default, the vehicle shall be deemed unclaimed and may be disposed of as an
abandoned or unclaimed vehicle, as otherwise provided in the Illinois vehicle
code.
   (I)   Liability For Penalty And Costs:
      1.   The owner of record of a motor vehicle that is seized or impounded
shall be liable to the village for an administrative fee, established by
Title 1, Chapter 20, “Fees, Fines, Insurance, Guarantees, and Regulatory
Measures”, in addition to any fees and charges for the towing and storage of
the motor vehicle by the applicable towing company.
      2.   Fees for towing and storage are established by the towing company
and not by the village, in accordance with the provisions of title 9, chapter 9
of this code.
      3.   A vehicle impounded pursuant to this section shall remain impounded
until the earlier of the following events occurs:
         (a)   The administrative fee is paid to the village, and all towing
and storage costs are paid to the applicable towing company.
         (b)   A bond in an amount equal to the liability of the owner as
provided in this section is posted with the village and all applicable towing
and storage costs are paid to the applicable towing company.
         (c)   The vehicle is deemed unclaimed or abandoned, in which case the
vehicle shall be disposed of in the manner provided by law for the disposition
of abandoned or unclaimed vehicles.
         (d)   Except as otherwise specifically provided by law, no owner, lien
holder or any other person shall be legally entitled to take possession of a
motor vehicle impounded under this section until the administrative fee and all
towing and storage costs applicable under this section have been paid in full.
(Ord. 2009-4250, 4-20-2009; amd. Ord. 2021-4921, 9-20-2021)

CHAPTER 2
PARKING RESTRICTIONS
SECTION:
10-2-1: Stopping, Standing Or Parking Prohibited In Certain Places
10-2-2: Restrictions Enumerated
10-2-3: Manner Of Parking Vehicles
10-2-4: Time Limit In Designated Places
10-2-5: Regulations Under Village Agreements
10-2-6: Parking For Handicapped Persons
10-2-6-1: Exemptions To Parking Restrictions
10-2-6-2: Handicapped Motorists Cards
10-2-6-3: Prohibitions
10-2-7: Penalty
10-2-8:    Electric Vehicles
10-2-1: STOPPING, STANDING OR PARKING PROHIBITED IN CERTAIN PLACES:
Except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic, or in compliance
with law or the directions of a police officer or official traffic control
device, no person shall:
   (A)   Stop, stand or park a vehicle 1 :
      1.   On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or
curb of a street;
      2.   On a sidewalk; (Ord. 451, 2-6-1973)
      3.   Beyond the edge of a driveway into any public right of way; (Ord.
2006-4021, 6-5-2006)
      4.   Within an intersection;
      5.   On a crosswalk;
      6.   Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within thirty feet
(30') of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of the safety zone,
unless a different length is indicated by signs or markings;
      7.   Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when
stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic;
      8.   Upon any bridge or other elevated structures or within a highway
tunnel, underpass or subway;
      9.   On any railroad tracks;
      10.   At any place where official signs prohibit stopping. (Ord. 451, 2-
6-1973; amd. Ord. 2006-4021, 6-5-2006)
      11.   At any place which is designated by official signs as a cab stand,
unless said vehicle is duly registered within the village, or is present at the
cab stand for the purpose of dropping off passengers who were initially picked
up outside of the village. (Ord. 93-2360, 2-15-1993; amd. Ord. 2006-4021, 6-5-
2006)
   (B)   Stand or park a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except momentarily
to pick up or discharge passengers:
      1.   In front of a public or private driveway;
      2.   Within fifteen feet (15') of a fire hydrant;
      3.   Within twenty feet (20') of a crosswalk at an intersection;
      4.   Within thirty feet (30') upon the approach to any flashing signal,
stop sign, yield sign or traffic control signal located at the side of the
roadway;
      5.   Within twenty feet (20') of the driveway entrance to any fire
station and on the side of the street opposite the entrance to any fire station
within seventy five feet (75') of such entrance (when properly signposted);
      6.   In front of curbside mailboxes located on School Street between Main
and Spencer;
      7.   At any place where official signs prohibit standing. (Ord. 88-1766,
12-5-1988)
   (C)   Park a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except temporarily for the
purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading merchandise or
passengers:
      1.   Within fifty feet (50') of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing;
      2.   At any place where official signs prohibit parking.
   (D)   Further, there shall be no parking:
      1.   On any street between two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00)
A.M. except by permission of the Police Department. (Ord. 451, 2-6-1973)
      2.   In any officially designated fire lane. Any person violating this
subsection (D)2 shall be fined as established by
Title 1, Chapter 20, “Fees, Fines, Insurance, Guarantees, and Regulatory
Measures” for each offense. (Ord. 96-2776, 5-20-1996; amd. Ord. 2021-4921, 9-
20-2021)
      3.   Where vehicle would reduce the usable width of a street to less than
eighteen feet (18'). (Ord. 451, 2-6-1973)
      4.   In a prohibited parking zone; or in a limited parking zone longer
than the time designated and authorized. Each continuing period of time equal
to the posted time limit shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 94-2603,
12-5-1994)
      5.   On private property without the consent of the owner of private
property. (Ord. 83-1136, 8-2-1983)

10-2-3: MANNER OF PARKING VEHICLES:
   (A)   Every vehicle stopped or parked upon a two-way roadway in the Village
shall be so stopped or parked with the right hand wheels parallel to and within
twelve inches (12") of the right hand curb or as close thereto as practicable
to the right hand edge of the right hand shoulder.
   (B)   Every vehicle parked in a compact car space shall not exceed the size
limitation indicated by the posted restriction and shall not protrude or
overhang any space limitation marked on the pavement. (Ord. 92-2321, 10-19-
1992)
   (C)   Any person failing to obey these restrictions shall be fined as
established by
Title 1, Chapter 20, “Fees, Fines, Insurance, Guarantees, and Regulatory
Measures” for each offense. (Ord. 96-2776, 5-20-1996; amd. Ord. 2021-4921, 9-
20-2021)
10-2-4: TIME LIMIT IN DESIGNATED PLACES:
   (A)   When And Where Prohibited:
      1.   Parking Prohibited During Snowfall: It shall be unlawful to park any
vehicle on any portion of any public street or highway in the Village during or
after any snowfall resulting in an accumulation of one inch (1") or more, and
for a period thereafter of twenty four (24) hours, or within such further
period as may be reasonably required to complete snow removal operations.
      2.   All Night Parking Prohibited: It shall be unlawful to park any
vehicle on any portion of any public street or highway in the Village between
the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M.
   (B)   Authority To Impound Vehicles: Whenever any vehicle is so parked
illegally as to obstruct the normal movement of traffic or interfere with the
sweeping or repair of streets or removal of snow therefrom, the Chief of
Police, or any person authorized by him, is hereby authorized to cause such
vehicle to be removed from the public street and conveyed by or under the
direction of a member of the Police Department to an authorized garage. The
Village shall be entitled to the fees provided in subsection (C) of this
section.
   (C)   Fees For Redemption: Before the owner or person entitled to the
possession of any impounded or removed vehicle shall be permitted to remove the
same from the custody of the Chief of Police, or person authorized by him, he
shall furnish satisfactory evidence of his identity and ownership of vehicle
and right of possession thereto, shall sign a receipt for the vehicle and in
addition to the fine provided for herein, shall pay the fee as established by
Title 1, Chapter 20, “Fees, Fines, Insurance, Guarantees, and Regulatory
Measures” for such vehicle to cover the cost of towing or removal of such
vehicle, and in addition thereto, the cost of storage charged by such
authorized garage at the prevailing rate for such storage.
   (D)   Central Business District: The total maximum time limit for parking a
vehicle within the Central Business District shall be two (2) hours, with the
exception of Municipal Lot G, which shall be four (4) hours. No vehicle shall
be moved from one (1) parking location to another parking location within the
Central Business District such that the vehicle is parked for a combined total
of more than two (2) hours for the entire area, nor shall any vehicle be moved
between a parking location within the Central Business District and Municipal
Lot G such that the maximum combined time limit of four (4) hours is exceeded.
The term "Central Business District" shall refer to that portion of the Village
bounded by Ogden, Garfield, Division and Center. (Ord. 79-830, 1-16-1979; amd.
Ord. 2003-3439, 1-20-2003; Ord. 2021-4921, 9-20-2021)

10-2-6: PARKING FOR HANDICAPPED PERSONS 1 :
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  10-4-5 of this title.
10-2-6-1: EXEMPTIONS TO PARKING RESTRICTIONS:
A motor vehicle bearing registration plates issued to a physically handicapped
person pursuant to 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-616 or to a disabled
veteran pursuant to 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-609 of the Illinois
Vehicle Code, effective July 1, 1970, as amended 2 , is hereby declared to be
exempt from any ordinance imposing time limitations on parking in a business
district; but otherwise is subject to the laws which prohibit parking in "no
stopping", "no standing" zones in front of or near fire hydrants, driveways,
public building entrances and exits, bus stops and loading areas, and is
prohibited from parking where the motor vehicle constitutes a traffic hazard
and the motor vehicle must be moved at the instruction and request of a law
enforcement officer to a location designated by the officer. Any motor vehicle
bearing registration plates specified in this section or similar registration
plates issued under the Vehicle Codes of other States, as amended, or
handicapped motorist's cards issued by the Village, as evidence that the
vehicle is operated by or for a handicapped person or disabled veteran, may
park, in addition to any other lawful place, in any parking place specifically
reserved, by posting of an official sign, for such vehicles. Parking privileges
granted by this section are strictly limited to those persons to whom the
special registration plates or cards are issued and to qualified operators
acting under such person's express direction while the disabled person is
present. No person shall use any area for parking of any motor vehicle pursuant
to 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-1303 of the Illinois Vehicle Code,
effective July 1, 1970, as amended, or where an official sign controlling such
area expressly prohibits parking at any time or during certain hours. (Ord. 80-
952, 9-16-1980)
 
Notes
2 2. 625 ILCS.
10-2-6-2: HANDICAPPED MOTORISTS CARDS:
The Business Office Manager shall issue, without charge, upon application of
any handicapped person or disabled veteran, a special handicapped motorist card
furnished by the Illinois Secretary of State, pursuant to the provisions of the
Illinois Vehicle Code, for the purpose of allowing said card to be used and
displayed on a vehicle being used to transport said handicapped person or
disabled veteran, but not owned or displaying a special handicapped or disabled
veteran's license plate, so as to identify said vehicle and entitle it to all
the parking privileges afforded to a vehicle possessing such special
handicapped or disabled veteran's license plates as hereinbefore provided. Such
card shall be issued only to handicapped persons or disabled veterans and the
same shall be displayed by hanging such card from the rearview mirror of the
vehicle and shall allow the vehicle to utilize special, handicapped parking
privileges when used to transport such handicapped person or disabled veteran.
The Village shall issue only temporary handicapped motorist cards. Requests for
permanent cards shall be directed to the Illinois Secretary of State.
For purposes of this section, a "physically handicapped person" shall mean
every natural person who is unable to walk two hundred feet (200') or more
unassisted by another person or without the aid of a walker, crutches, brace,
prosthetic device, or a wheelchair or without great difficulty or discomfort
due to the following impairments: neurologic, orthopedic, respiratory, cardiac,
arthritic disorder, blindness, or the loss of function or absence of a limb or
limbs.
All applicants shall complete an application form as provided by the business
office manager. Such form includes information which shall be completed by the
applicant and his or her physician. The physician shall designate whether the
handicap is temporary or permanent. If temporary, the physician must indicate
the length of the handicap. A temporary card will be issued for the designated
period not to exceed ninety (90) days. If an extension is needed, the applicant
must complete a new application and furnish proof of the reason for such
extension from the attending physician. No handicapped motorist vehicle card
shall be transferable. Use of any such card by any person other than the
handicapped person to whom it is issued except as provided herein, shall be
deemed a violation of this section and shall render the card void. Any abuse of
the card or unauthorized use shall render any such card subject to revocation.
No handicapped motorist card shall be issued until an application form is
completed and received by the business office manager. Providing false
information in the application filed with the business office manager shall be
deemed a violation of this section. (Ord. 2000-3185, 2-21-2000)
10-2-6-3: PROHIBITIONS:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle which is not bearing
registration plates to a physically handicapped or to a disabled veteran,
pursuant to the applicable sections of the Illinois motor vehicle code, or
similar registration plates duly issued under the motor vehicle code of another
state, or handicapped motorist card issued by the village or such decal, cards,
or devices issued by other municipalities pursuant to the authority granted to
them under the Illinois vehicle code as the local authorities of other
municipalities deem proper as evidence that the vehicle is operated by or for a
handicapped person or disabled veteran, in any parking place for motor vehicles
bearing such registration, plates, decals, cards or devices. Violation of this
section shall carry a fine as established by
Title 1, Chapter 20, “Fees, Fines, Insurance, Guarantees, and Regulatory
Measures” for each offense.
   (B)   The parking spaces located at or near the addresses listed below shall
be designated for handicapped parking. However, said list shall not be
interpreted as being inclusive of all such spaces within the village, nor shall
such designation limit the effect or enforcement of handicapped parking
prohibitions in locations other than listed below:
4710 Main Street
4739 Main Street
(Ord. 88-1652, 3-21-1988; amd. Ord. 96-2776, 5-20-1996; Ord. 2021-4921, 9-20-
2021)
10-2-7: PENALTY:
Any person convicted in a court of law of any violation of the provisions of
this chapter shall be fined as established by
Title 1, Chapter 20, “Fees, Fines, Insurance, Guarantees, and Regulatory
Measures” for each offense. The procedure set forth in section
9-4-22 of this code may be used to settle and compromise a violation.
(Ord. 2003-3439, 1-20-2003; amd. Ord. 2021-4921, 9-20-2021)

use of electric vehicle-only parking by non-electric vehicles at both public
and private properties is prohibited.
   (B)   Public electric vehicle charging stations shall charge fees as
established by
Title 1, Chapter 20, “Fees, Fines, Insurance, Guarantees, and Regulatory
Measures”.
(Ord. 2024-5083, 7-15-2024)
CHAPTER 3

CHAPTER 4
MUNICIPAL PARKING LOTS
SECTION:
10-4-1: Definitions
10-4-2: Municipal Parking Lots Established
10-4-3: Permits Required; Fees
10-4-4: Designation Of Parking Spaces

10-4-9: Penalties
10-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the
meanings respectively ascribed to them:
MOTOR VEHICLE: A machine propelled by mechanical power designed to travel along
the ground by use of wheels, treads, runners, or slides and used to transport
person(s) or property or pull machinery and shall include, without limitation,
automobiles, trucks, trailers, motorcycles, motorized bicycles, tractors and
wagons.
PERMITTED VEHICLE: That vehicle registered in the village business office, for
which a permit is issued.
In addition, only those vehicles which are validly registered, as required by
the laws of the state of residence of the vehicle owner, may be permitted
vehicles under this definition.
PERMITTEE: The person to whom a permit is issued for the right to park in
commuter parking lots as the parking lots have been established for municipal
purposes. (Ord. 92-2310, 9-8-1992; amd. Ord. 94-2534, 6-6-1994; Ord. 94-2583,
9-19-1994; Ord. 2003-3794, 11-17-2003)
10-4-2: MUNICIPAL PARKING LOTS ESTABLISHED:
There are hereby established municipally owned and leased off street parking
lots, as follows:
 
      That property lying south of properties commonly known as 1014 and 1018
LOT A Burlington Avenue and north of the Burlington Northern right of way and
      lying west of Spencer Avenue to the curb line east of Main Street.
      That property lying south of Burlington Avenue and north of the
LOT B Burlington Northern right of way and lying west of Center Avenue and east
      of Spencer Avenue.
      That property lying south of Burlington Avenue and north of the
LOT C Burlington Northern right of way and lying west of a line running south
      of the former Lisle depot and east of Center Avenue.
      That property lying south of the Burlington Northern right of way north
LOT D of Front Street and lying west of the village of Lisle commuter station
      and west to the curb line just east of the Main Street tunnel.
      That property lying north of the Burlington Northern right of way, east
LOT E of the Burlington Northern/Lisle train station and west of the St.
      Joseph's Creek culvert.
LOT G That property known as 4717 through 4719 Garfield Avenue, lying between
      Ogden Avenue and Burlington Avenue. (Ord. 2003-3461, 5-19-2003)
 
10-4-3: PERMITS REQUIRED; FEES:
   (A)   General: Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful for any
person to park a motor vehicle in the above described village parking lots
without first obtaining a permit. Certain spaces in certain lots may be, from
time to time, designated by signs for purposes other than commuter parking or
public parking purposes. The uses for which certain spaces may be designated
shall include, but not be limited to, areas for village employees, handicapped
parking, loading zones, Burlington Northern agent parking, visitors' parking,
police use, or other specific uses as indicated by signs. For regulations
pertaining to bicycles, refer to chapter 6 of this title.
      1.   Validity Of Permits; Transfer Prohibited:
         (a)   All permits required by this section shall be valid only for the
permitted vehicle, which shall be owned or leased by the permittee and shall
have a state license number assigned thereto. Two (2) vehicles may be
registered under the same permit; provided, that both vehicles are owned or
leased by the permittee and are registered in the village business office under
the permittee's name. However, only one of said two (2) vehicles shall be
allowed to use the permit at any one time.
         (b)   The transfer of any permit required herein between vehicles
other than those registered to the permittee is strictly prohibited. Any
attempt to transfer any permit required herein shall result in an automatic
revocation of said permit and the imposition of a fine as hereinafter set
forth. Further, if any person violates this subsection (A)1 while he is on the
permit waiting list, he shall be automatically placed at the end of the waiting
list for a parking permit in addition to paying any applicable fines.
      2.   Permit Issuance: The village reserves the right to issue permits
based upon rules which, in the opinion of the corporate authorities, further
the public health, safety, comfort, morals and welfare of its citizens, and
which, in the opinion of the corporate authorities, are in the best interests
of the village. Such rules may include giving priority to village employees,
village residents or any other group of persons determined appropriate by the
corporate authorities of the village.
      3.   Fee Increase: The village reserves the right to increase the fee due
for a parking permit at any time prior to the effective date of the permit.
Notification of the increase and the effective date thereof shall be deemed
given upon passage of the ordinance modifying the fee.
      4.   Payment Of Fee Difference Required: Holders of permits which are not
yet effective at the time a fee increase ordinance is passed shall pay to the
village the difference between the new fee and amount previously paid for the
permit.
   (B)   Categories: For purposes of issuing the parking permits prescribed
herein, there shall be the following categories:
Category 1    Lots A, B, C, D and E.
Lots A, B, D, and E shall be operated as commuter parking lots for which
quarterly parking permits are issued. A portion of lot C shall be operated as a
commuter parking lot for which quarterly parking permits are issued. Other
portions of lot C shall be designated by signage as employee parking and
village hall visitor parking. When space is available, daily permits shall be
issued for portions of lot C and lot E in a manner as determined appropriate by
the business office manager.
Category 4    Lot G.
The aforementioned lot shall be used by the owners and operators of retail and
other businesses and residents of multi-family units located in the central
business district. As used in this subsection, the term central business
district shall refer to that portion of the village bounded by Ogden, Garfield,
Division and Center. In the issuance of parking permits for lot G, priority
shall be given to such owners and operators of businesses and residents of
multi-family units; however, if spaces remain available after being offered to
business owners and operators and residents of multi-family units, the business
office manager may issue permits to others, or provide free public parking as
deemed appropriate by the business office manager.
   (C)   Fees And Purchasing Procedure:
      1.   Parking permits shall be obtained from the village of Lisle business
office manager. Fees shall be as established by
Title 1, Chapter 20, “Fees, Fines, Insurance, Guarantees, and Regulatory
Measures”.
      2.   There is hereby established the following procedures for purchase of
quarterly parking permits:
         (a)   Permits shall be paid for in full and obtained from the business
office manager prior to five o'clock (5:00) P.M. on the last village business
day of the quarter preceding the quarter for which the permit is to apply.
         (b)   Failure to pay for and obtain a parking permit by five o'clock
(5:00) P.M. on the last business day of a quarter shall be deemed to be a
forfeiture of the permittee's parking permit without further notice on the part
of the village. However, if the permittee pays for and obtains the parking
permit within the first five (5) business days of the quarter to which the
permit applies, the business office manager, upon the payment of a late fee in
the amount as established by Title 1, Chapter 20, “Fees, Fines, Insurance,
Guarantees, and Regulatory Measures”, may reinstate and reissue the permit.
Further, if the permittee pays for and obtains the parking permit within six
(6) to fifteen (15) business days after the first day of the quarter to which
it applies, the business office manager, upon the payment of a late fee in the
amount as established by
Title 1, Chapter 20, “Fees, Fines, Insurance, Guarantees, and Regulatory
Measures”, may reinstate and reissue the permit. Upon the passage of fifteen
(15) days following the first day of the quarter, the permittee forfeits all
rights and privileges whatsoever in the permit and must reapply for a permit
pursuant to subsection (D) of this section.
         (c)   Failure to pay to the village any increase in parking permit
fees, as set forth in subsection (A)3 of this section, shall render the parking
permit void.
         (d)   Any person who has failed to pay any ticket issued pursuant to
this chapter, and due pursuant to the terms of this code, by five o'clock (5:
00) P.M. on the last village business day of the quarter to which the current
permit applies, shall be denied the issuance of a permit for the new quarter
until such tickets are paid in full.
   (D)   Permit Application: Every owner or operator of a motor vehicle
desiring a permit for such vehicle, shall file a permit application with the
village business office setting forth the name and address of the applicant,
the description of the vehicle for which the permit is desired, and the state
license number of the vehicle for which the permit is desired. The applicant
shall furnish proof of ownership and/or registration if it is requested by the
village. Upon satisfactory completion and acceptance of the application and
payment of the applicable permit fees hereinafter provided, the village may
issue a permit. Upon the issuance of a permit by the village business office,
the applicant shall be permitted to park said registered vehicle in the
appropriate village parking lot until the expiration or revocation of such
permit. In the event that no commuter parking permits are available for sale,
the village of Lisle may at its discretion maintain a wait list for commuter
parking permits as provided for in subsection (D)1 of this section. If any
applicant uses or attempts to use a permit in connection with the parking of a
vehicle not registered with the village business office; or if any applicant
uses or attempts to use a permit in connection with the parking of a vehicle
not owned or leased by said applicant; or if any applicant uses or attempts to
use a permit in any manner not authorized by this chapter, the applicant shall
be automatically placed at the end of the waiting list, the permit will be
revoked and fines shall be imposed as hereinafter set forth.
      1.   In the event that no commuter parking permits are available for
sale, the village of Lisle may at its discretion maintain a wait list for
commuter parking permits. In order to be placed on the wait list an application
must be submitted on a form provided by the business office and a fee paid as
required by
Title 1, Chapter 20, “Fees, Fines, Insurance, Guarantees, and Regulatory
Measures”. The applicant must be the individual in whose name the permit will
be issued. As permits are offered to those on the wait list, forty five percent
(45%) of available permits must be offered only to incorporated village of
Lisle residents in chronological order, with those residents on the list the
longest being offered permits first, and the remaining fifty five percent (55%)
of available permits offered without regard for residency in chronological
order, with those on the list the longest being offered permits first.
   (E)   Refund: Any owner or operator of a motor vehicle having secured such a
permit from the business office manager as provided in subsection (D) of this
section may obtain a partial refund according to the schedule as established by
Title 1, Chapter 20, “Fees, Fines, Insurance, Guarantees, and Regulatory
Measures” if the owner or operator desires to cancel said permit at some time
prior to its expiration.
   (F)   Display Of Permit: It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle in
any of the above described village parking lots without displaying the permit
required by this chapter in the following manner: 1) parking permits that are
required to be affixed to the windshield shall be prominently displayed in the
lower right hand corner (passenger's side) of the front windshield within a
twelve inch (12") radius of said lower right hand corner; 2) parking permits
that are required to be hung from the rearview mirror shall be hung from the
rearview mirror in a prominently displayed manner, and in no event shall such
permits be affixed to the rearview mirror or otherwise displayed in any manner
contrary to this subsection. It shall be the permittee's obligation to securely
affix or hang the required permit in the designated location as provided in
this subsection.
Notwithstanding the foregoing, no permit need be acquired nor displayed while
parking in lots B, C, D, and E for the period starting at two o'clock (2:00)
P.M. to two o'clock (2:00) A.M. each day Monday through Thursday and from two
o'clock (2:00) P.M. Friday to two o'clock (2:00) A.M. Monday. However, any
vehicles parked at any location upon a municipal parking lot shall comply with
all other parking restrictions and time limits as set forth in this chapter.
   (G)   Revenue: All revenues derived from the sale of permits as provided
under this section shall be deposited in the general corporate fund of the
village.
   (H)   Penalties, Fines:
      1.   Failure To Display Permit: Failure to display a permit on any
permitted vehicle shall be determined to be a violation for which a fine as
established by
Title 1, Chapter 20, “Fees, Fines, Insurance, Guarantees, and Regulatory
Measures” shall be assessed for each offense.
      2.   Failure To Secure Permit: Parking in any municipal parking lot
without a valid permit shall be deemed a violation for which a fine as
established by Title 1, Chapter 20, “Fees, Fines, Insurance, Guarantees, and
Regulatory Measures” shall be assessed for each offense.
(Ord. 92-2310, 9-8-1992; amd. Ord. 94-2534, 6-6-1994; Ord. 94-2583, 9-19-1994;
Ord. 2003-3461, 5-19-2003; Ord. 2005-3965, 11-7-2005; Ord. 2010-4357, 12-6-
2010; Ord. 2011-4382, 5-2-2011; Ord. 2014-4540, 8-18-2014; Ord. 2021-4921, 9-
20-2021)
10-4-4: DESIGNATION OF PARKING SPACES:
Parking spaces shall be designated by lines painted or durably marked on the
surface of the parking lot. (Ord. 92-2310, 9-8-1992)
10-4-5: PARKING RESTRICTIONS:
The following restrictions shall apply to parking upon municipal parking lots,
as regulated by this chapter:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful to park a vehicle in more than one parking space
as designated by curb and striping. The fine for violating this subsection
shall be as established by
Title 1, Chapter 20, “Fees, Fines, Insurance, Guarantees, and Regulatory
Measures”.
   (B)   Certain parking spaces in the aforesaid parking lots shall be
designated as parking spaces for disabled persons. Qualifications for parking
in aforesaid spaces shall be secured by the ability of the permittee to obtain
a disabled license plate for the vehicle for which the permit is secured from
the secretary of state. Violation of this subsection shall carry a fine as
established by
Title 1, Chapter 20, “Fees, Fines, Insurance, Guarantees, and Regulatory
Measures” for each offense. A citation written for a violation of this section
may be settled and compromised according to the procedures set forth in section
9-4-22 of this code and is subject to increase pursuant to subsection
9-4-22(F) of this code.
   (C)   It shall be prohibited in the aforesaid parking lots to back a vehicle
into a parking space except for police emergency vehicles. Violation of this
subsection shall carry a fine as established by Title 1, Chapter 20, “Fees,
Fines, Insurance, Guarantees, and Regulatory Measures” for each offense.
   (D)   It shall be unlawful to park, stand, or stop a vehicle in a manner
which blocks the progress of other vehicles through any aisle, or which blocks
a parking space. The foregoing shall not prohibit temporary stopping of a
vehicle if it is done for the purpose of waiting for the immediate exit of
another vehicle from a parking space, or if the stopped vehicle's progress is
impeded by traffic. The fine for violating this subsection shall be as
established by Title 1, Chapter 20, “Fees, Fines, Insurance, Guarantees, and
Regulatory Measures”. (Ord. 2003-3439, 1-20-2003; amd. Ord. 2003-3461, 5-19-
2003; Ord. 2021-4921, 9-20-2021)
10-4-6: HOURS LIMITED:
The following time limits shall apply to parking upon municipal parking lots,
as regulated by this chapter:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful to park a motor vehicle in any of the parking
lots described in section
10-4-2 of this chapter from two o'clock (2:00) A.M. until four thirty o'clock
(4:30) A.M. except in spaces that have been conspicuously marked with signs
stating that overnight parking is permitted, or as provided for in subsection
(D) of this section. Overnight parking in designated spaces in lot B shall only
be allowed from two o'clock (2:00) P.M. Friday through two o'clock (2:00) A.M.
Monday.
   (B)   No vehicle shall be parked in a space designated for overnight parking
for more than twenty four (24) hours in any seventy two (72) hour period,
except that there is no such time restriction from two o'clock (2:00) P.M.
Friday through two o'clock (2:00) A.M. Monday.
   (C)   Visitor parking in lot C shall be limited to the number of hours
specified by signage prior to two o'clock (2:00) P.M. on days that the village
hall is open, except that the business office manager may issue parking permits
for visitor spaces that allow for parking without such posted time limits. Time
limits specified by signage for visitor parking spaces are not in effect after
two o'clock (2:00) P.M. Monday through Friday, and on days that the village
hall is not open.
   (D)   At the discretion of the business office manager, overnight parking
permits may be issued for certain parking spaces in lot C or lot G.
   (E)   Certain spaces in lot G shall be designated by signage as free four
(4) hour parking. (Ord. 2011-4382, 5-2-2011)
10-4-7: COLLECTION OF PERMIT FEES:
For purposes of collection of permit fees in designated areas, only the
aforementioned provisions shall exclude the collection of permit fees for the
periods set forth in subsection
10-4-3(F) of this chapter. (Ord. 2003-3461, 5-19-2003; amd. Ord. 2003-3794, 11-
17-2003)
10-4-8: APPEAL PROCESS:
Whenever the village revokes or refuses to grant a permit, or when it is
claimed that the provisions of this chapter do not apply, or that the true
intent and meaning of this chapter have been misconstrued or wrongly
interpreted, the applicant or person affected may appeal from that decision to
the board of appeals, consisting of the village manager, the chief of police
and the street superintendent, by written notice filed in the office of the
business office manager within fifteen (15) days from the date of the decision
appealed. The board of appeals shall call a hearing on the appeal within
fifteen (15) days after receipt of the notice of appeal. The board shall render
a decision within no more than five (5) days after completing such hearing.
Nothing herein shall restrict the village from seeking immediate enforcement of
the regulations of this chapter in court, where the hazard involved requires
such action. This section shall not be interpreted to grant jurisdiction to the
board of appeals over claims pertaining to the validity or enforceability of
pending citations issued by the village for violations of this chapter. (Ord.
94-2563, 8-1-1994; amd. Ord. 94-2583, 9-19-1994)
10-4-9: PENALTIES:
Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, any person violating any
provision of this chapter shall be fined as established by
Title 1, Chapter 20, “Fees, Fines, Insurance, Guarantees, and Regulatory
Measures” for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on
each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 96-2776, 5-
20-1996; amd. Ord. 2021-4921, 9-20-2021)

10-5-3: RIGHT TURNS ON RED LIGHTS:
Right turns shall be and they are hereby prohibited on red lights at the
following intersections, and any person violating the provisions of this
section shall be subject to a fine as established by
Title 1, Chapter 20, “Fees, Fines, Insurance, Guarantees, and Regulatory
Measures” for each offense:
Northbound Indiana Avenue at Ogden Avenue, between the hours of four o'clock
(4:00) to six o'clock (6:00) P.M.
Northbound Main Street at School Street.
Northbound Route 53 at Main Street, between the hours of six o'clock (6:00)
A.M. to nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. and five o'clock (5:00) P.M. to seven o'clock
(7:00) P.M.
Southbound Route 53 at Short Street, on school days when children are present.
Westbound Short Street at Route 53, on school days when children are present.
(Ord. 2005-3921, 4-4-2005; amd. Ord. 2015-4591, 7-20-2015; Ord. 2021-4921, 9-
20-2021)
10-5-4: OTHER TURNING MOVEMENTS RESTRICTED:
   (A)   No vehicle shall be driven so as to cross the centerline of Main
Street between Ogden and Burlington Avenues, except when an obstruction makes
it necessary or when making a left turn into or from any alley, private road or
driveway. The driver of any vehicle shall not turn such vehicle so as to
proceed in the opposite direction on Main Street between Ogden and Burlington
Avenues, nor to enter a parking space located across the centerline.
   (B)   Operators of motor vehicles are hereby prohibited from turning left
when exiting the parking lot of Jewel Foods at Route 53 and Maple Avenue via
the southernmost of the two (2) driveways providing access from said parking
lot onto Route 53. This prohibition shall not apply to the northernmost
driveway of the two (2) driveways providing access from said parking lot onto
Route 53. Anyone found to have violated any provision of this subsection shall
be fined as established by
Title 1, Chapter 20, “Fees, Fines, Insurance, Guarantees, and Regulatory
Measures” for each violation.
   (C)   Reserved.
   (D)   Reserved.
   (E)   Reserved.
   (F)   Operators of motor vehicles are hereby restricted to making right hand
turns only from the right hand lane when traveling north on College Road at the
intersection of Abbeywood; provided, however, that this provision shall not
apply to RTA and other common carrier buses transporting members of the public.
   (G)   Operators of motor vehicles are hereby allowed only to turn right from
the driveways located on the north property line of the Amoco station at 1101
Warrenville Road, Lisle, Illinois.
   (H)   Operators of motor vehicles are hereby prohibited from making U-turns,
when traveling east on Warrenville Road, from Route 53 easterly to the village
corporate limits. (Ord. 90-2087, 9-4-1990; amd. Ord. 94-2579, 9-19-1994; Ord.
96-2776, 5-20-1996; Ord. 2021-4921, 9-20-2021)
10-5-5: SPECIAL RESTRICTIONS:
Operators of nonemergency motor vehicles are hereby prohibited from driving
upon, prohibited from allowing any nonemergency vehicle to occupy, and are
prohibited from in any way causing any nonemergency motor vehicle to traverse,
stop, back or stand in the driveway located immediately north of the village
hall/police station building from Main Street to Spencer Avenue. Anyone found
to have violated any provision of this section shall be fined as established by
the annual fee ordinance for each violation. (Ord. 96-2776, 5-20-1996)
10-5-6: PENALTIES:
Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, any person found violating any
provision of this chapter shall be fined as established by
Title 1, Chapter 20, “Fees, Fines, Insurance, Guarantees, and Regulatory
Measures” for each offense. (Ord. 96-2776, 5-20-1996; amd. Ord. 2021-4921, 9-
20-2021)
CHAPTER 6
BICYCLES
SECTION:
10-6-1: Definitions
10-6-2: Rules For Riding And Operating
10-6-3: Equipment
10-6-4: Traffic Regulations Applicable
10-6-5: Permits Required
10-6-6: Penalties
10-6-1: DEFINITIONS:
BICYCLE: Shall mean and include, a vehicle with two (2) tandem wheels, neither
of which are less than twenty inches (20") in diameter, with solid or pneumatic
tires, having a steering bar or wheel, a saddle seat and propelled by human
power.
OPERATE: The word to "operate" or any form or tense thereof, shall mean and
refer to the use, putting into action or causing to function of a bicycle by a
person mounted thereon.
In addition to the above definitions, any applicable definitions of the traffic
code shall be deemed to be included therein. (Ord. 173, 9-15-1964)
10-6-2: RULES FOR RIDING AND OPERATING:
   (A)   Riding Abreast: When more than two (2) persons in a group are
operating bicycles upon a roadway, they shall ride single file.
   (B)   Clinging To Vehicles: No person operating a bicycle shall cling or
attach himself or the bicycle to any other moving vehicle.
   (C)   Extra Passenger: No person operating a bicycle shall carry another
person on the handlebars of said bicycle.
   (D)   Emerging From Alley, Driveways And Garages: The operator of a bicycle
emerging from an alley, driveway, garage or private sidewalk shall stop the
bicycle immediately prior to driving onto or across a public sidewalk or onto
or across a public sidewalk line projected across an alley, and shall exercise
extreme care in making such movements.
   (E)   Intoxication; Drugs; Physical Inability: No person shall operate a
bicycle while under the influence of liquor or drugs or while physically or
mentally unfit to safely operate the same. (Ord. 173, 9-15-1964)
   (F)   Operating On Sidewalks: Except as hereinafter provided, bicycles may
be operated on sidewalks in public parks and in residence and nonresidence
districts, but in single file only. Under all circumstances, the rider shall
yield the right of way to pedestrians using the sidewalk, and due and proper
care shall at all times be exercised by the rider for the pedestrians. When
approaching a pedestrian on the sidewalk, the speed of a bicycle shall be
reduced to a speed which is no greater than necessary to continue the operation
of the bicycle without the rider dismounting, and shall not be increased until
the pedestrian has passed. No bicycle shall be operated upon the following
described public walks 1 :
      1.   That public walk extending from Meyer Drive to Bluebell Court and
lying between lots 38 and 39 and 57 and 58 in the subdivision known as Oakview
unit 4.
      2.   That public walk extending from the southeast edge of the Schiesher
School grounds to Larkspur Lane and from Larkspur Lane to Meadow Lane and lying
between lots 19 and 20, 30 and 31 and 45 and 46 in the subdivision known as
Oakview unit 1. (Ord. 2009-4241, 1-12-2009)
   (G)   Parking Bicycles: It shall be unlawful to park any bicycle in the
business district along buildings in such a manner as to interfere with
pedestrians, or along roadways where they may interfere with traffic, or with
persons getting into or out of motor vehicles. No person other than the owner
or operator shall move, or in any manner interfere with any bicycle properly
parked, nor shall any person interfere or in any manner hinder any person from
properly parking a bicycle, except that members of the police department and
fire department may move, or in proper cases, prevent the parking of the
bicycle when, in the judgment of the policemen and firemen, his action is
necessary in order to properly safeguard persons or property.
   (H)   Keep To Right: All bicycles when operated on roadways shall be kept to
the right and shall be operated as near as practicable to the right hand edge
of the roadway.
   (I)   Speed: No bicycle shall be operated at any time faster than is
reasonable or proper, and every bicycle shall be operated with reasonable
regard to the safety of the rider and of other persons and property.
   (J)   Trick Riding: No person shall, while operating a bicycle, indulge or
engage in any kind of trick or unsafe riding.
   (K)   Turns; Starting; Stopping: The operator of a bicycle on a roadway,
when making a right turn shall follow the right hand edge of the roadway, and
the operator of a bicycle on a roadway when making a left turn shall approach
the point of turning in the traffic lane nearest the center of the roadway. No
operator of a bicycle shall start, slow down, stop or attempt to turn without
first indicating such movement as provided by law. (Ord. 173, 9-15-1964; amd.
Ord. 83-1136, 8-2-1983)
   (L)   Chaining Of Bicycles To Public Property; Use Of Bike Racks: No bicycle
shall be chained, tied, or otherwise attached to any public property, other
than designated bike racks, including, but not limited to, fences, utility
poles, sign poles, parking meters, newspaper vending boxes, or handrails.
Bicycles chained, tied, or otherwise attached to any public property other than
designated bike racks may be removed and disposed of by the police department
without notice and without liability to the village.
   (M)   Time Restriction: Bicycles attached to public bike racks in excess of
twenty four (24) hours, other than those bicycles attached to public bike racks
located in commuter parking lots C and D and displaying a current village
permit as provided for in section
10-6-5 of this chapter, may be removed and disposed of by the police department
without notice and without liability to the village. (Ord. 2005-3965, 11-7-
2005)
 
Notes
1 1. See subsection
  9-4-22(E) of this code regarding fines.
10-6-3: EQUIPMENT:
   (A)   Lights: No bicycle shall be operated within the period from sunset to
sunrise without having a properly lighted headlight attached to the front of
the bicycle, visible under normal atmospheric conditions from the front thereof
for a distance of not less than five hundred feet (500') nor without having a
red light attached to the rear of the bicycle which is clearly visible from a
distance of five hundred feet (500') from the rear.
   (B)   Mechanical Condition: No person shall operate a bicycle which is not
in such mechanical condition so that it can be safely operated.
   (C)   Signaling Devices: Each bicycle shall be equipped with a mechanical or
electrical signaling device in good working order and audible at a distance of
fifty feet (50') when sounded. (Ord. 173, 9-15-1964; amd. Ord. 83-1136, 8-2-
1983)
10-6-4: TRAFFIC REGULATIONS APPLICABLE:
Every person operating a bicycle shall strictly observe all traffic signs and
signals and all other traffic rules and regulations applicable thereto, and
shall obey the orders and directions of every officer of the village authorized
to direct or regulate traffic. (Ord. 173, 9-15-1964; amd. Ord. 83-1136, 8-2-
1983)
10-6-5: PERMITS REQUIRED:
   (A)   General: Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful for any
person to attach a bicycle to a public bike rack in village commuter parking
lots C and D in excess of twenty four (24) hours without first obtaining a
permit.
   (B)   Permit Issuance: Permits are issued for twelve (12) month periods
beginning January 1 through December 31.
   (C)   Permit Application: Every owner or operator of a bicycle desiring a
permit for such bicycle, shall file a permit application with the village
business office setting forth the name, address, and phone number of the
applicant, and the description and serial number of the bicycle for which the
permit is desired. The applicant shall furnish proof of ownership if it is
requested by the village. Upon satisfactory completion and acceptance of the
application, the village may issue a permit. Upon the issuance of a permit by
the village business office, the applicant shall be permitted to park said
registered bicycle in the appropriate village parking lot until the expiration
